DT Article
TI An oasis for alien benthic Foraminifera in the Aegean Sea.
AU Meric, Engin
   Yokes, M. Baki (bakiyokes@halic.edu.tr) 
   Avsar, Niyazi
   Bircan, Cuneyt
SO Aquatic Invasions
VL 5
IS 2
PS 191-195
PD June 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.aquaticinvasions.net/2010/index2.html
AW http://www.aquaticinvasions.net/2010/AI_2010_5_2_Meric_etal.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The benthic foraminiferal fauna in Pamucak Cove (NW Kusadasi, Turkey)
   was investigated. A rich foraminiferal assemblage was observed around
   submarine springs, which were located 200 m off the coast. This
   foraminiferal assemblage is typical Mediterranean. However, the
   abundance of alien species is noteworthy. Fourteen alien foraminifera
   were found. Indo-pacific originated species; Quinqueloculina sp. C,
   Triloculina sp. A, Pyramidulina catesbyi (d'Orbigny), Brizalina simpsoni
   (Heron- Allen and Earland) and Amphistegina lessonii d'Orbigny were
   observed for the first time on the Turkish coastline. Specimens of
   Haddonia sp. and Cymbaloporetta plana (Cushman), abundantly observed in
   SW Antalya and Nodopthalmidium antillarum (Cushman), previously recorded
   from Iskenderun were also found in the study area, these are the first
   records for these species in the Aegean Sea. In addition, seven
   individuals of Euthymonacha polita (Chapman) were found around the
   springs, and this constitutes the first record of this species in the
   entire Mediterranean Sea.
C1 Yokes, M. Baki; Department of Molecular Biology and Genetics, Halic
   University, 34093 Findikzade, Istanbul, Turkey, Turkey.
EM bakiyokes@halic.edu.tr
SC Zoology
SN 1818-5487
BD Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Foraminiferida [Mediterranean Sea / Turkey, Aegean Sea, Kusadasi,
   Pamucak Cove / Faunal list; new record; benthon]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea
OR Foraminiferida (Granuloreticulosea): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14701001366
OA DOAJ Gold

PT J
AN ZOOR14610069378
DT Article
TI Molecular evidence for species separation in the water mite Hygrobates
   nigromaculatus Lebert, 1879 (Acari, Hydrachnidia): evolutionary
   consequences of the loss of larval parasitism.
AU Martin, Peter (pmartin@zoologie.uni-kiel.de) 
   Dabert, M.
   Dabert, J.
SO Aquatic Sciences
VL 72
IS 3
PS 347-360
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 25
AB In the present study, we used mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit I
   (COI) and nuclear D2 region of 28S rDNA sequence data to examine the
   taxonomic status of the water mite species Hygrobates nigromaculatus
   from two types of freshwater habitats: lentic (lakes) and lotic
   (streams). Previous hypotheses about (sub)species status of populations
   inhabiting lakes and streams based on differences in morphometric data
   and life-cycle strategy (parasitic vs. non-parasitic larvae) were
   strongly supported by molecular data. Levels of COI and D2 28S rDNA
   differentiation between lake and stream populations were much higher
   (ca. 18 and 7.5%, respectively) than those typically observed for
   populations of a single species. Both lake and stream populations showed
   similar high levels of gene diversity (Hd = 0.894 and 0.836,
   respectively). However, nucleotide within-population polymorphism was
   more than twice as high in lake populations as that in stream
   populations ([pi] = 1.33 and 0.60%, respectively). We hypothesize that
   the ancestral lake-dwelling population originated from a stream form
   with parasitic larvae (here: H. setosus nov. stat.). For the observed
   populations, H. nigromaculatus individuals could be separated from H.
   setosus by distinct morphometric characters. The loss of phoretic
   parasitic larvae greatly decreased dispersal ability of lake-dwelling
   mites and consequently also the gene flow between lake populations.
   Thus, relatively more differentiated genetic structure in lake
   populations probably results from a stronger isolation between
   particular lake habitats, but this hypothesis needs further extensive
   studies.
C1 Martin, Peter; Univ Kiel, Inst Zool, Olshaussenstr 40, Kiel, Germany,
   Germany.
EM pmartin@zoologie.uni-kiel.de
RI Martin, Peter/E-3110-2014
OI Martin, Peter/0000-0003-2230-6484; Dabert, Jacek/0000-0003-3449-5366;
   Dabert, Miroslawa/0000-0001-5930-3346
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine
   &Freshwater Biology
SN 1015-1621
BD Systematics; Taxonomy; Status; Genetics; Associations; Commensalism;
   Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Lentic water; Lotic water; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Hygrobates nigromaculatus [Molecular genetics / COI & nuclear D2 region
   rDNA sequences / Evidence for species separation] [Population genetics /
   Genetic diversity / ] [Phoresy / Loss of phoretic parasitic larvae / ]
   [Lake /  / ] [Stream /  / ] [Germany / North / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Hygrobates nigromaculatus - Lebert 1879 (Acari). 
   Hygrobates nigromaculatus setosus - Besseling 1942 (Acari): [Raised to,
   Hygrobates setosus, p. 355].

   nigromaculatus setosus, p. 355].

DT Article
TI Revision of the genera Pseudamnicola Paulucci 1878 and Mercuria Boeters
   1971 of Algeria with particular emphasis on museum collections
   (Gastropoda: Prosobranchia: Hydrobiidae).
AU Gloeer, Peter (gloeer@malaco.de) 
   Bouzid, Slimane
   Boeters, Hans D.
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 139
IS 1
PS 1-22
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB An extensive investigation of newly collected samples and more than 140
   samples of museum collections (Museum Paris and Geneva) of Pseudamnicola
   spp. as well as of Mercuria spp. of Algeria and Tunisia has been carried
   out. Nine of the formerly described Pseudamnicola spp, of which we
   believe that four species are synonyms of Pseudamnicola dupotetiana,
   could be found in the collections. In addition, nine Pseudamnicola spp.
   and two Mercurio spp. are described here as being new: Pseudamnicola
   boucheti n. sp., P. chabii n. sp., P. ghamizii n. sp., P. algeriensis n.
   sp., P. gerhardfalkneri n. sp., P. calamensis n. sp., P. fineti n. sp.,
   P. linae n. sp., P. rouagi n. sp., Mercurio bourguignati n. sp., and M.
   gauthieri n. sp.
C1 Gloeer, Peter; Schulstr 3, D-25491 Hetlingen, Germany, Germany.
EM gloeer@malaco.de
SC Zoology
SN 0003-9284
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Africa

   ]. 
   Mercuria bourguignati; Mercuria gauthieri; Pseudamnicola algeriensis;
   Pseudamnicola boucheti; Pseudamnicola calmensis; Pseudamnicola chabii;
   Pseudamnicola fineti; Pseudamnicola gerhardfalkneri; Pseudamnicola
   ghamizii; Pseudamnicola linae; Pseudamnicola rouagi [Algeria /  / New
   species].

   to species, P. 16]. 
   Mercuria bourguignati (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Algeria, P. 19]. 
   Mercuria gauthieri (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Algeria, P. 20]. 
   Pseudamnicola - Paulucci 1878 (Rissoidea): [Diagnostic characters, P. 6;
   Key to species, P. 6]. 
   Pseudamnicola algeriensis (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Algeria, P. 13]. 
   Pseudamnicola boucheti (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Algeria, P. 11]. 
   Pseudamnicola calmensis (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Algeria, P. 13]. 
   Pseudamnicola chabii (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Algeria, P. 11]. 
   Pseudamnicola fineti (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Algeria, P. 13].

TI Contributions to the knowledge of the Triviidae XX. A new species from
   the genus Niveria Jousseaume 1884 (Mollusca: Gastropoda: Prosobranchia).
AU Fehse, Dirk (dirk.fehse@rohde-schwarz.com) 
   Greco, Jozef
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 139
IS 1
PS 23-33
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Triviidae from the Caribbean Sea and adjacent Atlantic
   in the genus Niveria is described as N. harriettae n. sp. The new taxon
   is compared with apparently similar species.

TI New taxa of the subfamilies Neniinae and Garnieriinae (Gastropoda:
   Stylommatophora: Clausiliidae).
AU Nordsieck, Hartmut (hnords@t-online.de) 
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 139
IS 1
PS 45-69
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB In the present paper the knowledge of the subfamilies Garnieriinae and
   Neniinae (Clausiliidae) is increased by the description of one new genus
   and several new species taxa. These taxa are the following:
   Garnieriinae: Ptychauchenia n. gen. (type species: P. panhai n. sp.);
   Grandinenia pallidissima n. sp.; Neniauchenia tonkinensis n. sp.;
   Ptychauchenia panhai n. sp.; Neniinae: Columbinia (C.) elegans n. sp.;
   C. (C.) elegantula n. sp.; C. (C.) marcapatensis n. sp.; C.
   (Steatonenia) hemmeni n. sp.; Neniella macrosoma n. sp.;
   Pseudogracilinenia pulchricosta n. sp.; Symptychiella (S.) acuminata n.
   sp.; S. (S.). fratermajor n. sp.; Incaglaia (I.) angrandi soukupi n.
   subsp.; I. (1.) a. variegata n. subsp.; Parabalea bicolor undaticosta n.
   subsp.; P. gibbosula grisea n. subsp.; P. latestriata queroensis n.
   subsp.; P. parcecostata meridionalis n. subsp.; Peruinia peruana
   ervthrostoma n. subsp.; Pseudogracilinenia pulchricosta lamellicosta n.
   subsp.; Symptychiella (S.) bilamellata costulata n. subsp.; S. (S.) b.
   gracilicosta n. subsp.; S. (S.) b. laevigata n. subsp.

PT J
AN ZOOR14611080549
DT Article
TI Terrestrial mollusks of Andriantantely Massif, Eastern Madagascar, with
   descriptions of 36 new species (Gastropoda: Caenogastropoda; Pulmonata).
AU Emberton, Kenneth C.
   Slapcinsky, John (slapcin@flmnh.ufl.edu) 
   Campbell, Chelsey A.
   Rakotondrazafy, Judicael
   Andriamiarison, Tsitohaina N.
   Emberton, Josephine D.
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 139
IS 1
PS 71-141
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB An altitudinal transect and other collecting on the eastern side of
   Andriantantely Massif along the central-east coast of Madagascar
   resulted in 74 species of terrestrial mollusks including 36 new species:
   Acroptychia mahafznaritra n. sp., Boucardicus anjarae n. sp., B. avo n.
   sp., B. hetra n. sp., B. lalinify n. sp., B. mahavariana n. sp., B.
   matoatoa n. sp., B. menoi n. sp., B. peggyae n. sp., B. pulchellus n.
   sp., B. tantelyae n. sp., Cyathopoma anjombona n. sp., C. hoditra n.
   sp., C. iridescens n. sp., C. madio n. sp., C. matsoko n. sp., Fauxulu.s
   tsarakely n. sp., Gulella andriantanteliae n. sp., G. thompsoni n. sp.,
   Parvedentulina andriantanteliae n. sp., P. benjamini n. sp., P. jeani n.
   sp., P. paulavi n. sp., P. thompsoni n. sp., Ampelita owengriffithsi n.
   sp., Reticulapex michellae n. sp., Kalidos gora n. sp., Kalidos
   manotrika n. sp., Kalidos manta n. sp., Kaliella crandalli n. sp.,
   Microcystis albosuturalis n. sp., M fotsifotsy n. sp., M. vony n. sp.,
   Sitala burchi n. sp., S. mavo n. sp., and S. stanisici n. sp.
   Andriantantely Massif is one of few tracts of lowland native rainforest
   remaining along the central coast of eastern Madagascar. Given the
   richness and endemism of this eastern forest, it is imperative to survey
   more of the remaining lowland rainforests in the region, while they
   remain relatively intact and while this information has value for
   conservation efforts.
C1 Slapcinsky, John; Department of Malacology, Florida Museum of Natural
   History, Box 117800, Gainesville, FL 32611-7800, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI Two new species of the millipede genus Desmoxytes Chamberlin, 1923
   (Diplopoda: Polydesmida: Paradoxosomatidae) from caves in southern
   China.
AU Golovatch, S.I.
   Geoffroy, J.-J.
   Mauries, J.-P.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 19
IS 2
PS 57-61
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new parapatric species of Desmoxytes are described from caves in a
   karst area in Guangxi Province, southern China. D. scutigeroides sp n
   and D scolopendroides sp.n Both are possibly troglobites, this being
   especially true of D scutigeroides sp.n, in which the legs, antennae and
   paratergal spines are particularly long, the body is loose while the
   tegument often pallid. Both the species differ well from each other and
   the remaining, known congeners, all in Southeast Asia and southern
   China, chiefly by the length of the legs and antennae, as well as in
   certain details of tergal and male leg ornamentation, and in gonopod
   structure
C1 Golovatch, S.I.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Problems Ecol & Evolut, Leninsky
   Pr 33, Moscow, Russia, Russia.
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0136-006X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Habitat; Subterranean habitat; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Desmoxytes [Cave habitat /  / Distribution; systematics] [China / South
   / ].

TI Two new species of the millipede genus Trichopeltis Pocock, 1894
   (Diplopoda: Polydesmida: Cryptodesmidae) from Vietnam and China.
AU Golovatch, S.I.
   Geoffroy, J.-J.
   Mauries, J.-P.
   VandenSpiegel, D.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 19
IS 2
PS 63-72
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Trichopeltis are described: T. deharvengi sp.n. from
   a montane forest in southern Vietnam, and T latellai sp.n from two
   adjacent caves in Guizhou Province, southern China. One of these
   species, T. deharvengi sp.n not only shows some of the somatic and
   gonopod characters intermediate between those known to distinguish the
   tribes Trichopeltini and Otodesmini, but also seems to be especially
   similar to the type species T. bicolor (Pocock, 1894), from Sumatra This
   warrants a more conservative approach to be followed in refining the
   diagnosis and scope of this genus, with the synonymization of
   Trichopeltini under Otodesmini, syn.n., based upon the reconfirmed
   synonymy of Trichopeltis and Otodesmus. A key is compiled to all six
   currently known species of Trichopeltis
C1 Golovatch, S.I.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Problems Ecol & Evolut, Leninsky
   Pr 33, Moscow, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of the order Stemmiulida from Vietnam
   (Diplopoda).
FT Un nouveau genre et une nouvelle espece de l'ordre Stemmiulida du
   Viet-Nam (Diplopoda).
AU Mauries, J.-P.
   Golovatch, S.I.
   Geoffroy, J.-J.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 19
IS 2
PS 73-80
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new, anophthalmous and unpigmented troglophile, Eostemmulus coccus sp
   n, is described from Vietnam. Despite lacking the usual ocelli and
   primary oblique striations, it clearly belongs to the Stemmiulida, as
   based on other somatic characters (presence of spinnerets on the telson,
   laterally compressed segments, and alternating sternal structures) and
   thus represents the first record of this order from Indochina In its
   habitus. the new species resembles Stemmiulus deharvengi Mauries &
   Golovatch, 2007, described from Halmahera. Indonesia, but it clearly
   differs from that species and all others (about 150 taxa worldwide) in
   the male sexual characters (gonopods, paragonopods, first pairs of
   Ices). as well as by the structure of the enathochilarium (identical to
   that of the Chordeumatida) and the surprising position and shape of the
   spinnerets on the telson. A new genus, Eostemmulus gen n, is therefore
   proposed to accommodate the new species As its name suggests, the
   authors consider that this genus occupies a position close to the base
   of the phyloueny of Stemmulida, based on male sexual characters,
   particularly the conformation of the gonopods and paraeonopods
C1 Mauries, J.-P.; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Systemat & Evolut, Case
   Postale 53,61 Rue Buffon, Paris, France, France.
SC Zoology
SN 0136-006X

   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Stemmiulida [Asia / Indochina / New record].

   Thorell. 1895 = Hylyphantes birmanicus (Thorell. 1895). = fasciata

   Thorell. 1895 = Nasoona crucifera (Thorell, 1895), = N occipiialis

   Erigone). = Trematocephalus eustylis Simon. 1909. all syn n; while
   Erigone bhamoensis Thorell, 1898 is a nomen dubium Erigone Thorell. 1898
   = Nesticella mollicula (Thorell, 1898). comb n being transferred to
   Nesticidae.

AN ZOOR14611076055
DT Article
TI Multiple nuclear and mitochondrial genotyping identifies emperors and
   large-eye breams (Teleostei: Lethrinidae) from New Caledonia and reveals
   new large-eye bream species.
AU Borsa, Philippe (philippe.borsa@ird.fr) 
   Collet, Adeline
   Carassou, Laure
   Ponton, Dominique
   Chen, Wei-Jen
SO Biochemical Systematics and Ecology
VL 38
IS 3
PS 370-389
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 15
AB Species identification is fundamental to address questions about
   community ecology, biodiversity, conservation and resource management,
   at any life history stage. Current studies on fish larval ecology of
   tropical species are hampered by the lack of reliable and effective
   tools for identifying larvae at the species level. Emperors and
   large-eye breams comprise fish species from the perciform fish family
   Lethrinidae. They inhabit coastal and coral-reef habitats of the
   tropical Indo-Pacific, and they are important fishery resources. Their
   taxonomy is considered difficult and identification to species is often
   problematic. Lethrinidae larvae and juveniles can be identified on the
   basis of meristic counts at the sub-family level, but no further. In
   this study, we developed a set of polymorphic PCR markers (size
   polymorphisms at the intron regions from 4/5 nuclear protein-coding
   genes and single-strand conformation polymorphism of a 205-bp fragment
   at the mitochondrial 16S rRNA locus), to characterize 341 specimens from
   21 Lethrinidae species from New Caledonia (southwestern tropical
   Pacific). A genetic data-bank was constructed using the genotypes
   screened from the multiple gene loci of adult or sub-adult specimens
   used as references for these species. The 16S rRNA gene fragment was
   able to differentiate species for the genus Lethrinus, but it provided
   little diagnostic resolution among different species within the genus
   Gymnocranius. A combination of the 16S rRNA marker and 4 nuclear markers
   developed herein allowed to sort out species within Gymnocranius spp.
   from New Caledonia. Using genotype distributions at nuclear loci to test
   for reproductive isolation, we found that three apparently undescribed
   large-eye bream species may exist, provisionally referred to as
   Gymnocranius sp. A, sp. B and sp. C. Subsequent genotyping of 137
   Lethrinidae larvae collected from the bays of the Noumea peninsula, New
   Caledonia, found a total of three species (Lethrinus genivittatus,
   Lethrinus olivaceus and Gymnocranius sp. A). [copyright] 2010 Elsevier
   Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Borsa, Philippe; Ctr IRD Montpellier, IRD, 911 Ave Agropolis, Rennes,
   France, France.
EM philippe.borsa@ird.fr
RI Borsa, Philippe/AAC-7915-2019; Borsa, Philippe/D-4967-2015; Ponton,
   Dominique/B-4828-2009; Carassou, Laure/L-3425-2013; CHEN,
   Wei-Jen/A-2605-2008
OI Borsa, Philippe/0000-0001-9469-8304; Ponton,
   Dominique/0000-0003-2313-2543; CHEN, Wei-Jen/0000-0003-4751-7632;
   Carassou, Laure/0000-0001-8024-8038
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 0305-1978
BD Techniques; Genetics; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Lethrinidae [Genetic techniques / Multiple mitochondrial & nuclear
   genotyping / larva] [Identification techniques / Species identification
   / ] [Genotype /  / ] [South Pacific / New Caledonia / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes
OR Lethrinidae (Perciformes).

TI Description of Lecane yatseni sp n. (Rotifera: Monogononta: Lecanidae)
   from China.
AU Wei, Nan
   Xu, Runlin (xurunlin_1960@yahoo.com) 
SO Biologia (Bratislava)
VL 65
IS 3
PS 512-514
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Lecane yatseni sp. n., collected from the littoral of an artificial lake
   on Qi'ao island of the Pearl River estuary, Guangdong province, south of
   China, is described and figured. It is closely related to one of the
   commonest species of the genus, Lecane luna, resembling Lecane papuana,
   but distinguished by the presence of inwardly curved aculeated
   anterolateral spines and broad-based spine-formed projections close to
   the middle of the ventral head aperture margin.

PT J
AN ZOOR14610067409
DT Article
TI Incorporation of the invasive mallow Lavatera arborea into the food web
   of an active seabird island.
AU Hawke, David J. (hawked@cpit.ac.nz) 
   Clark, John McK.
SO Biological Invasions
VL 12
IS 6
PS 1805-1814
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 19
AB This study investigated the role of the invasive mallow Lavatera arborea
   in the terrestrial ecosystem of a flourishing seabird island in SE New
   Zealand using natural abundance stable isotope ratios (13C/12C; 15N/14N,
   reported as [delta]13C and [delta]15N). Foliage samples of L. arborea
   came from transects encompassing three distinct environments (plateau,
   slope, storm-washed flat) across the island. Samples of potential marine
   nutrient sources (beach-cast kelp; seabirds using the island) were also
   collected, to contextualise the L. arborea data. Samples of invertebrate
   taxa (exotic and indigenous) from multiple ecosystem guilds were
   hand-collected; a bee, a sap-sucking Homoptera, a litter-feeding
   tenebrionid beetle, various carrion-feeding flies, a predatory carabid
   beetle, a salticid spider, and (from a seabird cadaver) Dermestes sp.
   exuviae. Discarded skins from the gecko Hoplodactylus maculatus were
   collected from moulting sites. Highly enriched [delta]15N values showed
   that L. arborea from all three environments utilised seabird N, even
   though breeding seabirds were absent from the storm-washed flat. The
   isotopic signatures of the Homoptera, and the tenebrionid and carabid
   beetles could be accounted for entirely by food webs based on L.
   arborea. Bee and salticid spider isotopic signatures could be accounted
   for by varying contributions from L. arborea. The flies and Dermestes
   were (as expected) linked to carrion from either the island or the
   adjacent mainland. In contrast, gecko data indicated direct dependence
   on seabirds, although the exact relationship was unclear. Our study
   therefore showed that L. arborea is an integral part of the terrestrial
   ecosystem of the island across multiple trophic levels from pollinators
   to top-level predators.
C1 Hawke, David J.; Christchurch Polytech Inst Technol, Sch Appl Sci &
   Allied Hlth, POB 540, Christchurch, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM hawked@cpit.ac.nz
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1387-3547
BD Nutrition; Diet; Ecology; Trophic structure; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Australasia
DE Insecta [Food plants / Lavatera arborea / ] [Food webs / Invasive plant
   incorporation into food web / ] [New Zealand / Motunau Island / ]. 
   Invertebrata [Food webs / Invasive plant incorporation into food web / ]
   [New Zealand / Motunau Island / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda
OR Invertebrata (Animalia). 
   Insecta (Arthropoda). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14610067409
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI [Murexsul zezae n. sp. Italian Pliocene (Gastropoda: Muricidae).]
FT Murexsul zezae n. sp. del Pliocene Italiano (Gastropoda: Muricidae).
AU Brunetti, M. Mauro
   Forli, Maurizio (info@dodoline.it) 
SO Bollettino Malacologico
VL 46
IS 1
PS 4-8
PD guigno 2010
PY 2010
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Murexsul zezae n. sp. is described from the Early Pliocene (Zanclean) of
   Italy, based on 23 specimens from three localities in Liguria and
   Tuscany. Main shell characters of the new species are the biconical
   profile with six axial ribs on the last whorl. The spiral cords
   (IP-P1-P2-P3-P4-P5-P6-ADP-MP-ABP) and the internal denticles (D1-D5)
   were identified according to the method described by Merle (2001). The
   most similar species are Murex revolutus Bellardi, 1873 and Murex
   cirratus Bellardi, 1873 from the Miocene of the Piedmont. Murexsul zezae
   n. sp is compared with other Neogene and Recent species from the
   European- Mediterranean area
C1 Forli, Maurizio; Via Grocco 16, Prato, Italy, Italy.
EM info@dodoline.it
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0394-7149

PT J
AN ZOOR14701003983
DT Article
TI First incursion of Nipponorthezinella guadalcanalia (Hemiptera:
   Ortheziidae) into Britain, with a revised checklist and key to the
   British Ortheziidae.
AU Malumphy, C.
   Davie, K.
SO British Journal of Entomology and Natural History
VL 23
IS 2
PS 65-72
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In August 2009, a large infestation consisting of tens of thousands of
   Nipponorthezinella guadalcanalia (Morrison) (Hemiptera: Ortheziidae) was
   found in composted bark around the roots of potted Amomum sp. plants and
   an Alpinia sp. plant at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Edinburgh, Scotland.
   All the plants had been imported as dry seeds, except one that was
   imported as a rhizome from South East Asia. This is the first incursion
   of this species into Britain. The biology and geographical distribution
   of N. guadalcanalia are reviewed. In addition, a revised key and
   annotated checklist of the nine species (five native and four
   non-established introductions) of ortheziid recorded in Britain are
   presented.
C1 Malumphy, C.; The Food and Environment Research Agency, Sand Hutton,
   York Y041 1LZ, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
SC Zoology
SN 0952-7583
BD Systematics; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation; Publications; Zoogeography;
   Dispersal; Means of dispersal; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe; United Kingdom
DE Nipponorthezinella guadalcanalia [Introduction /  / New record]
   [Scotland /  / ]. 
   Ortheziidae [Checklists /  / ] [United Kingdom / Britain / Key to
   species] [ /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Coccoidea
OR Nipponorthezinella guadalcanalia (Coccoidea): [New record].

AB One new species of the genus Taphroderoides Scivittaro, 1975, and new
   records for Neotropical species of Stereodermus Lacordaire, 1866
   (Coleoptera, Brentidae). A new species of the genus Taphmderoides
   Scivittaro, 1975 (Taphroderinae), is described from French Guiana,
   illustrated and compared to the only other known species of the genus.
   T. doctus (Kleine, 1927). One new synonymy and new country records are
   proposed for Neotropical species of the genus Stereodermus Lacordaire,
   1866 (Cyphagoginae).

PT J
AN ZOOR14609064221
DT Article
TI Occurence of Xiphidiopsis lita Hebard, 1922, on Mascarene and Seychelles
   islands (Orthoptera, Ensifera).
FT Presence de Xiphidiopsis lita Hebard, 1922, aux Mascareignes et aux
   Seychelles (Orthoptera, Ensifera).
AU Hugel, Sylvain (hugels@inci-cnrs.unistra.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 115
IS 2
PS 167-173
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Occurence of Xiphidiopsis lita Hebard, 1922, on Mascarene and Seychelles
   islands (Orthoptera, Ensifera). Xiphidiopsis lita Hebard, 1922, was
   described from Hawaii and is widely distributed on Pacific islands. This
   species is recorded for the first time on Mascarene islands (Mauritius,
   Rodriguez and Reunion). X. lita is also present on Seychelles where it
   was recorded as Amytta sp. A diagnosis of this widely distributed
   species is given, its world distribution is reviewed, and possible
   factors favouring this distribution are discussed.
C1 Hugel, Sylvain; Univ Strasbourg, CNRS, 21 Rue Rene Descartes,
   Strasbourg, France, France.
EM hugels@inci-cnrs.unistra.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0037-928X

   New record] [Seychelles /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Xiphidiopsis lita (Saltatoria): [New record].

TI Nomenclatural changes for the actualization of the catalog of the
   neotropical Arctiinae (Lepidoptera, Arctiidae).
FT Changements nomenclaturaux en vue de l'actualisation du catalogue des
   Arctiinae neotropicales (Lepidoptera, Arctiidae).
AU Vincent, Benoit (amastus@gmail.com) 
   Laguerre, Michel
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 115
IS 2
PS 175-184
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB Nomenclatural changes for the actualization of the catalog of the
   neotropical Arctiinae (Lepidoptera, Arctiidae). In view of a nearby
   update of the neotropical Arctiinae catalogue, 27 synonymies, 15 genus
   changes, 2 species revalidations and one status change are proposed.
   These modifications are supported by morphological and molecular data.

DT Article
TI Taxonomical note on Pogonocherini from French Guiana (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
FT Note taxonomique sur les Pogonocherini de Guyane francaise (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
AU Touroult, Julien (touroult@wanadoo.fr) 
   Tavakilian, Gerard Luc
   Dalens, Pierre-Henri
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 115
IS 2
PS 193-202
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Taxonomical note on Pogonocherini from French Guiana (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Lamiinae). Five new Lamiinae from French Guiana are
   described: Cosmotomidius nigrisetosus n. sp., C. elongatus n. sp., C.
   morvanae n. sp., C. cacaoensis n. sp. et C. crudiaphilus n. sp. Zikanita
   egregia Martins & Galileo, 2007, is transfered to the genus
   Cosmotomidius. We propose to place the genus Cosmotomidius in
   Pogonocherini Mulsant, 1939, and a key to the eight species of the genus
   is provided. Lypsimena brasiliensis Aurivillius, 1922, is synonymised
   with Lypsimena fuscata Haldeman, 1847, and recorded for the first time
   from French Guiana.
C1 Touroult, Julien; SEAG, 15 Ave Christophe Colomb, Soyaux, France,
   France.
EM touroult@wanadoo.fr

   Systematic position of Peritelus ruficornis Brisout, 1863 (Coleoptera,
   Curculionidae, Entiminae). Peritelus ruficornis Brisout, 1863, is

TI Description of a new species of Montandoniola Poppius, 1909, from
   Nigeria (Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Anthocoridae).
FT Description d'une nouvelle espece de Montandoniola Poppius, 1909, du
   Nigeria (Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Anthocoridae).
AU Streito, Jean-Claude (streito@supagro.inra.fr) 
   Matocq, Armand
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 115
IS 2
PS 211-214
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Description of a new species of Montandoniola Poppius, 1909, from
   Nigeria (Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Anthocoridae). A new species of
   Montandoniola from Nigeria is described. It is characterized by
   prominent eyes, very developed in males, much less developed in females,
   and by male and female genitalia. The difference in eyes development is
   the first reported case of conspicuous sexual dimorphism in the genus.
   The habitus, the genitalia are described and illustrated.
C1 Streito, Jean-Claude; Campus Int Baillarguet, Lab Natl Protect Vegetaux,
   Montferrier Sur Lez, France, France.
EM streito@supagro.inra.fr

TI Aphaenops (Cerbaphaenops) bourdeaui Coiffait, 1976, a second
   biogeographical enigma revisited (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
FT Une seconde enigme biogeographique revisitee : Aphaenops (Cerbaphaenops)
   bourdeaui Coiffait, 1976 (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Trechinae).
AU Faille, Arnaud (faille@mnhn.fr) 
   Fresneda, Javier
   Bourdeau, Charles
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 115
IS 2
PS 219-224
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Aphaenops (Cerbaphaenops) bourdeaui Coiffait, 1976, a second
   biogeographical enigma revisited (Coleoptera, Carabidae). Aphaenops
   (Cerbaphuenops) bourdeaui Coiffait, 1976, is one of the species the most
   poorly known of Carabidae fauna of France. Morphologically extremely
   close to species from Ariege and Haute-Garonne, the species known by the
   two only exemplars of the typical serie is isolated in a cave of Western
   Pyrenees. Study of the two specimens allowed to discover that holotype
   and paratype, cited as females in the original description, are males. A
   detailed morphological study of these exemplars, especially genitalia,
   allows us to establish the synonymy A. crypticola Linder = A. bourdeaui
   Coiffait, n. syn.
C1 Faille, Arnaud; MNHN, UMR CNRS 7205, CP 50,45 Rue Buffon, Paris, France,
   France.
EM faille@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0037-928X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Aphaenops crypticola - Linder 1859 (Carabidae): [Syn nov, Aphaenops
   bourdeaui Coiffait 1976, p. 223].

DT Article
TI Phylogeny of the genus Morpho Fabricius, 1807, revisited (Lepidoptera,
   Nymphalidae).
AU Cassilde, Catherine (cassilde@mnhn.fr) 
   Blandin, Patrick
   Pierre, Jacques
   Bourgoin, Thierry
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 115
IS 2
PS 225-250
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Although the genus Morpho Fabricius, 1807, is an important component of
   the international butterfly trade, it is still poorly understood
   phylogenetically. The first phylogenetic analysis of the genus, based on
   morphological characters, was published in 2002, and its results
   contested the monophyly of three of the nine recognized subgenera, and
   suggested abandoning the subgeneric classification altogether. The
   present study re-evaluates the characters used previously, and adds new
   data derived from the microstructure of the wing scales. In contrast to
   previous studies, eight of the nine subgenera were recovered as
   monophyletic. M. absoloni was confirmed to be closely related to M.
   aurora within subgenus Balachowskyna. Subgenus Cytheritis was found to
   comprise two widely separated monophyletic groups centered on M. portis
   and M. marcus. The latter is described as a new subgenus. However, the
   evolutionary relationships among the subgenera remain poorly supported,
   except for two clades each composed of two subgenera: (Morpho, Pessonia)
   and (Iphimedeia, Laurschwartzia). We then use this new phylogeny to gain
   further understanding of the evolution of the famous blue wing
   coloration of certain Morph species. In particular, we demonstrate that
   not all blue Morpho are blue in the same way.
C1 Cassilde, Catherine; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Systemat & Evolut,
   Paris, France, France.
EM cassilde@mnhn.fr
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Evolutionary Biology

   position; General morphology; Appendages; Colour and luminescence;
   Integument; Integumentary derivatives; Reproduction; Reproductive
   system; Evolution
DE Morpho [Wings / Wing morphology / taxonomic implications] [Colour / Wing

DT Article
TI Myrmeleon mariaemathildae n. sp.: a new Mediterranean pit-building
   antlion (Neuropterida Myrmeleontidae).
AU Pantaleoni, Roberto A. (r.pantaleoni@ise.enr.it) 
   Cesaroni, Carlo
   Aldini, Rinaldo Nicoli
SO Bulletin of Insectology
VL 63
IS 1
PS 91-98
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new Mediterranean species of antlion, Myrmeleon mariaemathildae n.
   sp., is described on material from Sardinia (Italy) and Tunisia. The new
   species, small in size with a relatively pale habitus, can be
   distinguished from all the other known species of Myrmeleon in the West
   Palearctic area on the basis of a set of chromatic characteristics,
   external morphological features, and the morphology of the internal male
   genitalia. The characteristics which differentiate it from Myrmeleon
   inconspicuus Rambur 1842. the only other species with which it could be
   confused, are discussed in detail. A preliminary description of the
   third instar larva is also provided. From a bio-ecological point of
   view, M. mariaemathildae n. sp. is associated with coastal dune
   environments colonized almost exclusively by grassy vegetation in which
   the larvae often build their pits close to Ammophila plants. The new
   species, where present, shows a perfect differentiation of its coastal
   dune habitat with other species: M. inconspicuus and Myrmeleon hyalinus
   Olivier 1811 in Sardinia: these and others are being studied in Tunisia.
C1 Pantaleoni, Roberto A.; ISE CNR, Traversa Crucca 3,Reg Baldinca, Li
   Punti SS, Italy, Italy.
EM r.pantaleoni@ise.enr.it

TI How many subspecies of Coal Tit Periparus ater are there in Iran?
AU Kirwan, Guy M. (GMKirwan@aol.com) 
   Grieve, Andrew
SO Bulletin of the British Ornithologists' Club
VL 130
IS 2
PS 83-87
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We discuss subspecific limits in Coal Tit Periparus ater in Iran and
   immediately adjacent regions. Three races are generally accepted as
   occurring in the country, one of them, P. a. phaeonotus, known only from
   four specimens collected in the Zagros Mountains of south-west Iran. We
   speculate that the type series Of the latter taxon might have been
   incorrectly labelled as to date, and that the species is only a rare
   winter visitor to this region of the country. The other subspecies
   listed as occurring in Iran, P. a. gaddi and P. a. chorassanicus, are
   only extremely doubtfully distinct from phaeonotus.

DT Article
TI Studies of Socotran birds VI. The taxonomic status of the Socotra
   Buzzard.
AU Porter, R.F. (richardporter@dialstart.net) 
   Kirwan, Guy M.
SO Bulletin of the British Ornithologists' Club
VL 130
IS 2
PS 116-131
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The resident, short-winged Buteo population on Socotra, despite having
   been known for over 110 years, has never been formally named. Now that
   it has been extensively studied in the field and its characters
   understood, we believe that it should be described. Like all other
   members of the B. buteo superspecies (sensu Kruckenhauser et al. 2003),
   it is relatively poorly differentiated genetically from most Old World
   buzzards, but is closest to B. (b.) bannermani of the Cape Verde Islands
   and the comparatively widespread Long-legged Buzzard B. rufinus of the
   southern Palearctic. It shares morphological features with several other
   Afrotropical buzzards, especially B. oreophilus, and B. buteo vulpinus,
   but is clearly well differentiated from B. rufinus and B. (b.)
   bannermani in this respect. Taxonomic judgements concerning this
   superspecies are inherently problematic because it represents an
   obviously recent radiation and because of difficulties in establishing
   which characters might be considered taxonomically informative. We elect
   to describe this population at species rank to highlight its highly
   unusual position within the superspecies, both genetically and
   morphologically. Finally, we present notes on its breeding biology
   (season September April), population size (<250 pairs), behaviour
   (similar to Common Buzzard B. buteo), diet (reptiles and invertebrates),
   moult (November to April) and conservation prospects (the taxon should
   probably be ranked as Vulnerable according to IUCN criteria).
C1 Porter, R.F.; c/o BirdLife International, Wellbrook Court, Girton Road,
   Cambridge, CB3 ONA, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM richardporter@dialstart.net
SC Zoology
SN 0007-1595

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   121].

   118]. 
   Buteo socotraensis (Accipitridae): [Sp nov, Yemen, P. 119].

DT Article
TI Palaeocope ostracods from the Silurian Wenlock Series of Arctic Canada.
AU Miller, C. Giles (G.Miller@nhm.ac.uk) 
   Williams, Mark
   Siveter, David J.
SO Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences
VL 47
IS 6
PS 913-925
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Silurian Wenlock Series deposits of the Cape Phillips Formation on
   Baillie-Hamilton Island and Cornwallis Island, Arctic Canada, have
   yielded a silicified ostracod assemblage that spans the late
   Sheinwoodian and Homerian stages. Sixteen palaeocope ostracod species
   are recorded, including the new species Beyrichia (Beyrichia) marssae,
   Gabrielsella? copelandi, and Platybolbina (Abruptobolbina) adraini. The
   ostracod faunas can be linked into local trilobite, microverte- brate,
   and graptolite zonal schemes, and a few of the ostracod species offer
   potential for local and perhaps wider biostratigraphical correlation.
   The ostracods are mostly known only from the Cape Phillips Formation,
   but also include two taxa found in the Wenlock Series of the Avalanche
   Lake area, Northwest Territories, Canada. Other ostracod species suggest
   links with Silurian successions in northern Canada and the Baltic.
   Low-diversity ostracod faunas characterize the level of a marked
   positive carbon isotope excursion and coeval mid-Homerian regression at
   the level of the regional Pristiograptus dubius - Gothograptus nassa
   graptolite Biozone. Comparison with the pattern of distribution of
   coeval ostracod faunas elsewhere in Canada suggests that diversity
   changes in the Cape Phillips Formation ostracod faunas are controlled by
   local palaeoenvironmental factors perhaps linked to global sea-level
   change.

   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

TI A primary study on species diversity of water birds and its relationship
   to water environment at Lake Jinyinhu, Wuhan.
AU Luo, Sha
   Hu, Hong-xing
   Cheng, Shui-ping
   He, Feng
   Wu, Zhen-bin (wuzb@ihb.ac.cn) 
SO Changjiang Liuyu Ziyuan Yu Huanjing
VL 19
IS 6
PS 671-677
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB During the investigation on water birds at Lake Jinyinhu from Nov. 2007
   to Mar. 2009, 34 birds species of 11 families 8 orders were recorded, in
   which there were 21 winter migrant species, 6 summer migrant species, 5
   resident species and 2 passengers. In terms of geographical distribution
   type, there were 21 Palaearctic species, 2 Oriental species and 11
   cosmopolitan species. Platalea leucorodia, listed on both Rank II
   National Protected Wildlife and China Red Data Book of Endangered
   Animals,was recorded. And there were 10 species protected provincially.
   According to the feeding habits of water birds, there were more spedes
   living on fish and shrimp, but more biomass of the species living on
   hydrophytes. The water quality of Lake Jinyinhu turned out to be even
   poorer than the 5th level, were analyzed, The bird diversity index in
   different seasons and different habitats were analyzed. It indicated
   that the reconstruction of hydrophytes and the change of wate-land area
   by water level control would increase the biodiversity of Lake Jinyinhu.
   Furthermore, the species diversity of water birds and environmetn
   condition were compared between urban and suburban lakes of Wuhan. The
   result showed that the water bird diversity correlated negatively with
   the pollution degree, positively with the area of lakes. Thus the over
   development and encroachnent of wetlands should be prohibited,and it is
   urgent to improve the water quality.

DT Article
TI Genetic and Morphological Variation Between Populations of the
   Pascagoula Map Turtle (Graptemys gibbonsi) in the Pearl and Pascagoula
   Rivers with Description of a New Species.
AU Ennen, Joshua R. (joshua.ennen@usm.edu) 
   Lovich, Jeffrey E.
   Kreiser, Brian R.
   Selman, W.
   Qualls, Carl P.
SO Chelonian Conservation and Biology
VL 9
IS 1
PS 98-113
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 15
AB Cryptic or undescribed species pose a major problem in conservation
   biology. Managing multiple unresolved taxa collectively as a single
   entity could precipitate the loss of unrecognized genetic variation and
   unique populations and, possibly, lead to extinction of undiscovered or
   unrecognized taxa. In contrast to other species in its clade, the
   Pascagoula map turtle (Graptemys gibbonsi), as currently recognized, is
   not confined to a single major river system (or a cluster formed by a
   major river and adjacent minor drainages) but occurs in two major river
   systems, the Pearl and Pascagoula Rivers. We analyzed G. gibbonsi
   samples from both rivers for the first time in a morphological and
   molecular assessment of the taxonomic status of this poorly studied
   species. We compared the extent of genetic differentiation
   (mitochondria! DNA; mtDNA) between G. gibbonsi populations with members
   within the pulchra clade and between Graptemys oculifera and Graptemys
   flavimaculata. We found significant carapace pattern variation and
   morphological differentiation between the Pearl and Pascagoula river
   samples of G. gibbonsi. Our mtDNA sequences showed greater genetic
   differentiation between G. gibbonsi samples from the Pearl and
   Pascagoula rivers than between two recognized and reciprocally sympatric
   species, G. oculifera (Pearl River) and G. flavimaculata (Pascagoula
   River), but revealed only a modest degree of differentiation when
   compared to other members of the pulchra clade. Based on the degree of
   differentiation in 1) morphology, 2) color patterns, and 3) mtDNA, in
   addition to their 4) allopatric distributions, we describe a new species
   from the Pearl River, restricting the species G. gibbonsi to the
   Pascagoula River.
C1 Ennen, Joshua R.; Univ So Mississippi, Dept Biol Sci, Hattiesburg, MS,
   USA, USA.
EM joshua.ennen@usm.edu
OI Lovich, Jeffrey/0000-0002-7789-2831

   Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary
   Biology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 1071-8443

   luminescence; Colour; Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution; Habitat;
   Freshwater habitat; Lotic water; Zoogeography; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA

DT Article
TI First ceratopsid dinosaur from China and its biogeographical
   implications.
AU Xu, Xing (xingxu@vip.sina.com) 
   Wang, KeBai
   Zhao, XiJin
   Li, DunJing
SO Chinese Science Bulletin
VL 55
IS 16
PS 1631-1635
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB Ceratopsid dinosaurs represent one of the best known dinosaur groups in
   the Late Cretaceous, and their unquestionable fossil records are
   exclusively restricted to western North America. Here we report a new
   ceratopsid dinosaur, Sinoceratops zhuchengensis gen. et sp. nov., from
   the Upper Cretaceous Wangshi Group of Zhucheng, Shandong Province,
   China. Cladistic analysis places this new taxon as the only known
   ceratopsid from outside North America, in a basal position within the
   Centrosaurinae. It is considerably larger than most other centrosaurines
   but similar in size to basal chasmosaurines. Furthermore, it is more
   similar to chasmosaurines than to other centrosaurines in several
   features, thus blurring the distinction of the two ceratopsid subgroups.
   This new find not only provides significant information on the
   morphological transition from non-ceratopsid to ceratopsid dinosaurs,
   but also complicates the biogeography of the Ceratopsidae, and further
   demonstrates that fossil sampling has profound effects on reconstructing
   dinosaurian biogeography.
C1 Xu, Xing; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Vertebrate Paleontol & Paleoanthropol,
   Beijing, China, China.
EM xingxu@vip.sina.com
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 1001-6538
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Ceratopsidae [Phylogeny /  / new record] [Zoogeography /  / ] [China / 
   / ] [Cretaceous / Upper Cretaceous / ]. 
   Sinoceratops [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Sinoceratops zhuchengensis [Shandong /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  /
   ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Ornithischia,
   Ceratopsia

   Sinoceratops (Ceratopsia): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Centrosaurinae, Type
   species Sinoceratops zhuchengensis, p. 1632, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Sinoceratops zhuchengensis (Ceratopsia): [Sp nov, Shandong, Cretaceous,
   P. 1632; Fossil].

DT Article
TI The phylogenetic relationships of the charismatic poster frogs,
   Phyllomedusinae (Anura, Hylidae).
AU Faivovich, Julian (julian@macn.gov.ar) 
   Haddad, Celio F.B.
   Baeta, Delio
   Jungfer, Karl-Heinz
   Alvares, Guilherme F.R.
   Brandao, Reuber A.
   Sheil, Christopher
   Barrientos, Lucas S.
   Barrio-Amoros, Cesar L.
   Cruz, Carlos A.G.
   Wheeler, Ward C.
SO Cladistics
VL 26
IS 3
PS 227-261
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 30
AB The leaf or monkey frogs of the hylid subfamily Phyllomedusinae are a
   unique group of charismatic anurans. We present a molecular phylogenetic
   analysis that includes 45 of the 60 species of phyllomedusines using up
   to 12 genes and intervening tRNAs. The aims were to gain a better
   understanding of the phylogenetic position of Phrynomedusa, test the
   monophyly and explore the relationships among several putative lineages
   (Hylomantis, the H. buckleyi Group, Phasmahyla, the four species groups
   of Phyllomedusa, and the species of Phyllomedusa that remain unassigned
   to any group), and to examine the implications of our phylogeny for the
   evolution of several characters in phyllomedusines. The analyses
   resulted in a well-supported phylogenetic hypothesis that provides a
   historical framework for a discussion of the evolution of characters
   associated with reproductive biology, gliding behaviour, the physiology
   of waterproofing, and bioactive peptides. Implications include an
   earlier origin for eggless capsules than for leaf-folding behaviour
   during amplexus, two independent origins of gliding, and an earlier
   origin of reduction in evaporative water loss than uricotelism, which is
   a result that originally was predicted on the basis of physiology alone.
   Furthermore, our results support the prediction that bioactive peptides
   from different peptide families are to be expected in all species of
   Phyllomedusinae. Hylomantis (as recently redefined) is shown to be
   paraphyletic and the synonymy of Agalychnis is revised to remedy this
   problem by including both Hylomantis and Pachymedusa. <(C)> The Willi
   Hennig Society 2009.
C1 Faivovich, Julian; CONICET, Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat, Angel Gallardo
   470,C1405DJR, Buenos Aires, DF, Argentina, Argentina.
EM julian@macn.gov.ar

   F. B./C-4267-2012; , Reuber/N-5217-2019; Brandao, Reuber A/A-3427-2013

TI A NEW SPECIES OF ATHOUS ESCHSCHOLTZ IN THE SUBGENUS ORTHATHOUS REITTER
   (COLEOPTERA: ELATERIDAE) FROM TURKEY.
AU Kabalak, Mahmut (mahmut@hacettepe.edu.tr) 
   Sert, Osman
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 64
IS 2
PS 119-121
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Athous (Orthathous)yozgatiensis Kabalak and Sert, new species, from
   Yozgat, Turkey is described. Photograph of the adult, drawings of the
   antenna and aedeagus, a key to the new and closely related species, a
   distribution map, and differential diagnosis table are given. The new
   species is similar to Athous kovancii Platia and Athous fragariae Platia
   and Kovanci, but is distinguished clearly by the second antennal segment
   slightly longer than wide, third antennal segment longer than second,
   and broadly rounded apex of parameres.

DT Article
TI DISCOVERY OF THE SKIFF BEETLE GENUS YARA REICHARDT AND HINTON
   (COLEOPTERA : MYXOPHAGA HYDROSCAPHIDAE) IN VENEZUELA, WITH DESCRIPTION
   OF A NEW SPECIES.
AU Short, Andrew E.Z. (aezshort@ku.edu) 
   Joly, Luis J.
   Garcia, Mauricio
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 64
IS 2
PS 151-156
PD June 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Neotropical skiff beetle genus Yara Reichardt and Hinton is recorded
   from Venezuela for the first time, marking the first discovery of the
   genus since its original description in 1976. The Venezuelan species,
   Yara maculata Short, Joly, and Garcia, new species, is described and
   illustrated, bringing the total number of species in the genus to three.
   It is currently known from several localities along the northwestern
   edge of the Guiana Shield. The presence of a mat of recumbent setae on
   tergite IV, often considered diagnostic for the family, is found to be
   absent in Yam. A key to the three species is provided as well as
   observations on the habitat and seasonality of the new species.
C1 Short, Andrew E.Z.; Univ Kansas, Dept Ecol & Evolutionary Biol,
   Lawrence, KS, USA, USA.
EM aezshort@ku.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0010-065X

   Neotropical region; South America

   Yara maculata [Venezuela /  / New species].

DT Article
TI Non-avian theropod dinosaurs from the Early Late Cretaceous of central
   Europe.
AU Osi, Attila (hungaros@freemail.hu) 
   Apesteguia, Sebastian
   Kowalewski, Michal
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 31
IS 3
PS 304-320
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB Quantitative and qualitative analyses of isolated teeth and postcranial
   elements of non-avian theropod dinosaurs from the Upper Cretaceous
   (Santonian) Csehbanya Formation, lharkut (western Hungary) indicate that
   these remains represent multiple dinosaur groups. Based on comparative
   and statistical analyses, 58 teeth and tooth fragments are identified as
   belonging to medium-sized basal tetanuran theropods that may have
   represented the top-predator of the terrestrial lharkut ecosystem. These
   teeth are almost identical with the two 'Megalosaurus pannoniensis'
   teeth from the lower Campanian of Muthmannsdorf (Austria) and show a
   notable similarity to teeth of the Middle Jurassic M. bucklandii and the
   Lower Cretaceous 'M. dunkeri from England. A single pedal ungual phalanx
   is interpreted as the oldest European occurrence of Late Cretaceous
   abelisaurids, as suggested by a ventral groove and bifurcated grooves
   laterally bordering a convex, triangular area. Small-bodied paravian
   theropods are found to be the best represented group in lharkut,
   including teeth, caudal vertebrae, a metacarpal III, manual phalanges,
   and a fragmentary left tibia. A particularly notable paravian remain is
   a complete left scapulocoracoid possessing a unique pneumatic foramen
   ventral to the coracoid foramen. This specimen is assigned to
   Pneumatoraptor fodori n. g. et sp. Finally, numerous postcranial
   elements of Theropoda indet. were recovered, including a fragmentary
   sacrum that offers new insights into the sacral pneumaticity of
   theropods. The presence of these theropods in the Santonian Iharkut
   ecosystem provides the first evidence that during the early Late
   Cretaceous the Mediterranean archipelago was inhabited by both Gondwanan
   and Euramerican members of theropod dinosaurs. Consistent with data
   available for other archosaurian taxa, the close relationship of the
   basal tetanuran teeth with much older forms suggests that the lharkut
   area may have functioned as a refugium in the early Late Cretaceous
   Mediterranean archipelago. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Osi, Attila; Hungarian Acad Sci, Hungarian Nat Hist Museum, Ludovika Ter
   2, Budapest, Hungary, Hungary.
EM hungaros@freemail.hu
RI Kowalewski, Michal/B-4263-2008; Osi, Attila/K-2414-2018; Apesteguia,
   Sebastian/F-4034-2018
OI Kowalewski, Michal/0000-0002-8575-4711; Osi, Attila/0000-0003-2967-997X;
   Apesteguia, Sebastian/0000-0002-0414-0524
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 0195-6671

   Skeleton; Dentition; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Abelisauridae; Tetanurae [Teeth / Tooth anatomy / systematics]
   [Zoogeography / Palaeozoogeography / ] [Hungary / Bakony Mountains / ]

DT Article
TI Lower Cretaceous ammonites from the Neuquen Basin, Argentina: the
   neocomitids of the Pseudofavrella angulatiformis Zone (upper
   Valanginian).
AU Aguirre-Urreta, Maria B. (aguirre@gl.fcen.uba.ar) 
   Rawson, Peter F.
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 31
IS 3
PS 321-343
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Pseudofavrella angulatiformis Zone (upper Valanginian) of the Agrio
   Formation in the Neuquen Basin, Argentina, is characterized exclusively
   by a complex sequence of neocomitid faunas that are sandwiched between
   the olcostephanids of the underlying Viluceras permolestus Subzone
   beneath and the holcodiscid faunas of the Holcoptychites neuquensis Zone
   above (lowermost Hauterivian). Three successive neocomitid genera,
   Pseudofavrella, Chacantuceras and Decliveites gen. nov., characterize
   three subzones. Over half the taxa are new: Pseudofavrella robusta, P.
   sp. nov. 1 and 2, Chacantuceras casanuestraense, Chacantuceras
   coniunctum, Decliveites crassicostatus, and Decliveites agrioensis. (C)
   2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Aguirre-Urreta, Maria B.; Univ Buenos Aires, CONICET, Pabellon 2,Ciudad
   Univ, Buenos Aires, DF, Argentina, Argentina.
EM aguirre@gl.fcen.uba.ar

SN 0195-6671

DT Article
TI Three new species of the genus Arsenura Duncan, 1841 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Drei neue Arten der Gattung Arsenura Duncan, 1841 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 3
PS 10-14
PD Juni 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of the genus Arsenura DUNCAN, 1841 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured: A. yungascymonia n. sp. from NW
   Bolivia (La Paz department., N. Yungas province), A. altocymonia n. sp.
   from high altitudes in Cusco dep. (SE Peru) and A. kaechi n. sp. from
   Ecuador. All holotypes ex coil. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk, and Frank
   MEISTER, Prenzlau, are deposited in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany),
   which later, together with this collection, will be included in
   Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. The preimaginal
   instars of the new taxa are unknown to us.

   Arsenura yungascymonia (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 10].

DT Article
TI Arsenura paraorbignyana n. sp., a new species of the genus Arsenura
   Duncan, 1841 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Arsenura paraorbignyana n. sp., eine neue Art der Gattung Arsenura
   Duncan, 1841 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 3
PS 15-19
PD Juni 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Arsenura DUNCAN, 1841 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae), A. paraorbignyana n. sp., is described from NE Argentina
   (Misiones dep.) and S(E) Paraguay, and both sexes figured. The holotype
   [male] (ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk) is deposited in coll. Museum
   WITT, Munich (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will
   be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany.
   The preimaginal instars of the new species are unknown to us.
   Furthermore, A. angulatus BOUVIER, 1924 stat. rev. is removed from
   synonymy with A. orbignyana (GUERINMENEVILLE, (1844)) and reinstated as
   a full species. The orbignyana-species group (sensu LEMAIRE 1980: 57),
   which comprises A. orbignyana (GUERIN-MENEVILLE, (1844)), A. angulatus
   BOUVIER, 1924 stat. rev., A. paraorbignyana n. sp. andA. xanthopus
   (WALKER, 1855), is discussed.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de

DT Article
TI Notes on the moorei species-group of of the genus Ambulyx Westwood, 1847
   with descriptions of new taxa (Lepidoptera, Sphingidae).
FT Einige Anmerkungen zur moorei-Gruppe der Gattung Ambulyx Westwood, 1847
   mit Beschreibung neuer Taxa (Lepidoptera, Sphingidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Kitching, Ian J.
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 3
PS 20-26
PD Juni 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three new taxa of the genus Ambulyx WESTWOOD, 1847 (Lepidoptera:
   Sphingidae) are described and figured: Ambulyx celebensis banggaiensis
   n. ssp. from the Banggai Archipelago, Indonesia (Peleng I., Sula I.),
   Ambulyx dohertyi novoirlandensis n. ssp. from the island ofNew Ireland
   (Papua New Guinea [PNG)) and Ambulyx dohertyi novobritannica n. ssp.
   from the island of New Britain (PNG). All holotype [male] [male], ex
   coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (Germany), are deposited in coll. Museum
   WITT, Munich (and will eventually be incorporated into the Zoologische
   Staatssammlungen Muenchen/Munich, Germany). The preimaginal instars of
   the new taxa remain unknown. All three taxa belong to the "red" Ambulyx
   moorei MOORE, (1858) species-group. In addition, Ambulyx amboynensis
   ROTHSCHILD, 1894 stat. rev. (= Oxyambulyx felixi CLARK, 1924) is raised
   to full species rank; and Ambulyx dohertyi queenslandi (CLARK, 1928)
   stat. rev. is removed from synonymy with Ambulyx dohertyi ROTHSCHILD,
   1894 and treated as a subspecies thereof. Finally, Ambulyx flava (CLARK,
   1924) stat. nov. and Ambulur flavocelebensis BRECHLIN, 2009 stat. nov.
   are also raised to full species status.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Notes on the genus Copaxa Walker, 1855 with descriptions of eighteen new
   taxa (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Einige Anmerkungen zur Gattung Copaxa Walker, 1855 mit Beschreibung von
   Achtzehn neuen Taxa (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 3
PS 27-55
PD Juni 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eighteen new taxa of the genus Copaxa WALKER, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) are described and figured: C. rudloffi n. sp. from Costa
   Rica (type locality (TL)) and Nicaragua, C. paranjinans n. sp. from
   Mexico (Oaxaca (TL), Veracruz, Chiapas), C. yungescens n. sp. and C.
   yungaskoenigoides n. sp. both from NW Bolivia (N Yungas (La Paz dep.)),
   C. schmiti n. sp. from Nicaragua, C. conlani n. sp. from Costa Rica (TL)
   and Panama, C. wernermeisteri n. sp. from Mexico (Chiapas), C. kitchingi
   n. sp. from NW Peru (Piura (TL), Lambayeque), C. vanschayck-i n. sp.
   fromN Peru (San Martin (TL), Amazonas), C. madrediosiana n. sp. from SE
   Peru (Madre de Dios (TL), Cusco), C. mielkeorum n. sp. from SE Brazil
   (Bahia (TL), Santa Catarina, Para), C. pascoandensis n. sp. from C Peru
   (Pasco), C. cuscoandensis n. sp. from SE Peru (Cusco), C. yungaspandens
   n. sp. from NW Bolivia (N Yungas (La Paz dep.)), C. cuscoexpandens n.
   sp. from SE Peru (Cusco), C. satipoexpandens n. sp. from C Peru (Junin),
   C. lavenderoguatemalensis n. sp. from Guatemala and finally C.
   chrisbrechlinae n. sp. from NW Peru (Piura). All holotypes (ex coll
   Ronald BRECHLIN & Frank MEISTER) are deposited in coll. Museum WITT,
   Munich (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will be
   included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany. All
   new species are assigned to species groups (sensu LEMAIRE 1978). In
   addition to those recognized previously, two further species groups are
   established, the expandens and the cydippe species groups. Both the
   decrescens and the canella species groups have been divided into two
   subgroups. Furthermore C. marona SCHAUS, 1906 stat. rev., C. rufotincta
   ROTHSCHILD, 1895 stat. nov. and C. ockendeni (DRUCE, 1906) stat. rev.
   are removed from synonymy with C. decrescens WALKER 1855, C.
   multifenestrata (HERRICH-SCHAEFFER, 1858) and C. medea (MAASSEN, 1890)
   respectively and treated as full species. A checklist of the entire
   genus including its species groups is given.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de
SC Zoology

   zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North America; Central
   America; South America

   Copaxa schmiti [Nicaragua /  / New species]. 
   Copaxa yungaskoenigoides; Copaxa yungaspandens; Copaxa yungescens
   [Bolivia /  / New species].

   Copaxa kitchingi (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 33]. 
   Copaxa lavenderoguatemalensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Guatemala, P. 39].
   
   Copaxa madrediosiana (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 34]. 
   Copaxa marona - Schaus 1906 (Saturniidae): [Removal from synonymy, With

   Copaxa ockendeni (Druce 1906), p. 27]. 
   Copaxa mielkeorum (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 34]. 
   Copaxa multifenestrata - (Herrich-Schaeffer 1858) (Saturniidae):
   [Removal from synonymy, Copaxa rufotincta Rothschild 1895, p. 27]. 
   Copaxa ockendeni - (Druce 1906) (Saturniidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Copaxa medea (Maassen 1890), p. 27]. 
   Copaxa pararufinans (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 28]. 
   Copaxa pascoandensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 36]. 
   Copaxa rudloffi (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Costa Rica, P. 28]. 
   Copaxa rufotincta - Rothschild 1895 (Saturniidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Copaxa multifenestrata (Herrich-Schaeffer 1858), p. 27]. 
   Copaxa satipoexpandens (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 37].

   Copaxa yungaspandens (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 37]. 
   Copaxa yungescens (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 29].

AB Two new species of the genus Salassa MOORE, 1859 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae), S. kitchingi n. sp. from Nepal and S. meisteri n. sp. from
   Bhutan, are described and figured: Both holotype [male] [male] (ex coll.
   Ronald BRECHLIN) are deposited in coll. Museum WITT, Munich, which
   later, together with this collection, will be incorporated into the
   Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen, Munich, Germany. Both new taxa
   should be nearest to S. Zola (WESTWOOD, 1847) and S. belinda WITT &
   PUGAEV, 2007. In addition, S. bhutanensis BRECHLIN, 2009 stat. rev. is
   reinstated in full species rank.

DT Article
TI Four new species of the genus Psilogramma Rothschild & Jordan, 1903
   (Lepidoptera, Sphingidae).
FT Vier neue Arten der Gattung Psilogramma Rothschild & Jordan, 1903
   (Lepidoptera, Sphingidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Kitching, Ian J.
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 3
PS 66-74
PD Juni 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four new species of the genus Psilogramma ROTHSCHILD & JORDAN, 1903
   (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae) are described and figured: P. timorica
   BRECHLIN & KITCHING n. sp. from (W) Timor (Indonesia, Nusa Tenggara
   Timur province), P. manusensis BRECHLIN & KITCHING n. sp. from Manus I.
   (Papua New Guinea, Manus province), P. exigua BRECHLIN, LANE & KITCHING
   n. sp. from N, NW and SW(?) Australia, and P. makirae BRECHLIN &
   KITCHING n. sp. from San Cristobal ((= Makira), Solomon Islands,
   Makira-Ulawa province). The holotype [male] of P. exigua n. sp. is
   deposited in Australian Museum, Sydney, NSW, Australia; all the other
   three holotype [male] [male] (ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN) are deposited in
   coll. Museum WITT, Munich, which later, together with this collection,
   will be incorporated into the Zoologische Staatssammlungen Muenchen,
   Munich, Germany. The preimaginal instars of the new species remain
   unknown. Furthermore, we reinstate P. tanimbarica BRECHLIN, 2001 stat.
   rev., P. papuensis BRECHLIN, 2001 stat. rev., P. sundana BRECHLIN, 2001
   stat. rev., P. kitchingi BRECHLIN & LACHLAN, 2001 stat. rev. and P.
   sulawesica BRECHLIN, 2001 stat. rev. as the valid names for these five
   species and respectively synonymise with them: P. karui EITSCHBERGER,
   2001 syn. nov.; P. mastrigti EITSCHBERGER, 2001 syn. nov.;
   P.gerstbergeri EITSCHBERGER, 2001 syn. nov.; P. wernerwol EITSCHBERGER,
   2001 syn. nov.; and P. milleri EITSCHBERGER, 2001 syn. nov.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Freidberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.

   Ecuador (Esmeraldas province) and probably Mexico (Chiapas), R. aricia

DT Article
TI An aphidiine parasitoid Monoctonia vesicarii (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)
   and three chalcidoid hyperparasitoids of Pemphigus matsumurai
   (Homoptera: Aphididae) forming leaf galls on Populus maximowiczii in
   Japan.
AU Takada, Hajimu (sukkui@aol.com) 
   Kamijo, Kazuaki
   Torikura, Hidenori
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 2
PS 205-215
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 8
AB More than 300 unopened leaf galls formed by the pemphigine aphid
   Pemphigus matsumurai on Populus maximowiczii were collected at
   Nakasatsunai, Hokkaido, Japan, in July and September 2007 and kept in
   cold conditions during winter. From mummified fundatrices in the galls
   an aphidiine parasitoid Monoctonia vesicarii and three species of
   hyperparasitoids belonging to Pteromalidae, Eupelmidae and Eulophidae
   emerged from March to May 2008. Monoctonia vesicarii, which is new to
   Japan, is redescribed. The eulophid hyperparasitoid is described as a
   new species, Aprostocetus (Aprostocetus) doronokianus, and the
   pteromalid and eupelmid hyperparasitoids are identified as Pachyneuron
   sp. and Eupelmus sp., respectively. Approximately 180 unopened mummies
   of P. matsumurai were dissected in August and November 2008 and a living
   larva of M. vesicarii was found in each of 17 of them. These
   observations suggest that some individuals of M. vesicarii pass through
   two-year cycles. The implications of the three species of
   hyperparasitoids to P. matsumurai galls are discussed.
C1 Takada, Hajimu; 40 Ogura Cho,Sakyo Ku, Kyoto, Japan, Japan.
EM sukkui@aol.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Developmental Biology
SN 1343-8786
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Life cycle and
   development; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect
   parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia
DE Aprostocetus (Aprostocetus) doronokianus [Hemipteran hosts / Pemphigus
   matsumurai / New parasite species] [Hymenopteran hosts / Monoctonia
   vesicarii / ] [Japan /  / New species from hemipteran host] [ /  / New

DT Article
TI Taxonomic status of Amebachia Uchida in the genus Netelia Gray
   (Hymenoptera; Ichneumonidae; Tryphoninae) with descriptions of four new
   species from Japan.
AU Konishi, Kazuhiko (konishi@affrc.go.jp) 
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 2
PS 216-225
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The lectotype of Amebachia baibarana Uchida, 1928, which is the type
   species of Amebachia Uchida, was re-examined. Though this species was
   synonymized with Netelia (Netelia) laevis (= Paniscus laevis Cameron,
   1905) and Amebachia has been synonymized under the subgenus Netelia of
   the genus Netelia, it is concluded that A. baibarana is a distinct
   species from N. laevis and Amebachia should be a subgenus of the genus
   Netelia. Netelia laevis is transferred from the subgenus Netelia to
   Apatagium. Four new species of Netelia (Amebachia), N. (A.) yoshimatsui
   sp. nov., N. (A.) rasilella sp. nov., N. (A.) fulvistigma sp. nov., and
   N. (A.) vicinalis sp. nov. are described from Japan, and a key to the
   species of this subgenus is provided.
C1 Konishi, Kazuhiko; Natl Agr Res Ctr Hokkaido Reg, Hitsujigaoka 1,
   Sapporo, Hokkaido, Japan, Japan.
EM konishi@affrc.go.jp

DT Article
TI First fungus gnats of genus Manota Williston (Diptera: Mycetophilidae)
   from Japan.
AU Hippa, Heikki
   Kjaerandsen, Jostein (jostein.kjaerandsen@zool.lu.se) 
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 2
PS 226-233
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Manota is recorded from Japan for the first time. Three new
   species, Manota satoyamanis, Manota indahae and Manota tunoae spp. nov.,
   are described, based on specimens collected in an ecological sampling
   program of arthropods in the "satoyama" landscape of Ishikawa
   Prefecture. "Satoyama" represents the traditional rural landscape of
   Japan, which is characterized by a mosaic of secondary forests,
   plantations, ponds and rice paddy fields. The new species raise the
   number of Palearctic Manota species from five to eight.

   Sweden, Sweden.

   species].

DT Article
TI Taxonomic review of the genus Pseudostegania Butler, 1881, with
   description of four new species and comments on its tribal placement in
   the Larentiinae (Lepidoptera: Geometridae).
AU Han, Hongxiang
   Stuening, Dieter
   Xue, Dayong (xuedy@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 2
PS 234-249
PD Jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The genus Pseudostegania Butler is revised. In addition to the two
   species known, four species are described as new: P. lijiangensis sp.
   nov. from Yunnan Province, P. qinlingensis sp. nov. from Gansu and
   Shaanxi Provinces, P. zhoui sp. nov. from Sichuan Province (China) and
   P. burmaensis sp. nov. from Burma (Myanmar); two species are newly
   combined with Pseudostegania: P. distinctaria (Leech, 1897), comb. nov.
   and P. yargongaria (Oberthur, 1916), comb. nov. All the known species
   are redescribed and lectotypes are designated for P. defectata
   (Christoph, 1881), P. distinctaria and P. yargongaria. The generic
   characters, based on all species, are summarized. The tribal placement
   of Pseudostegania is discussed. Illustrations of moths and genitalia are
   presented.
C1 Xue, Dayong; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Zool, 1 Beichen W Rd, Beijing,
   China, China.
EM xuedy@ioz.ac.cn

DT Article
TI Investigation of the dispersion pattern of animal populations in a casy
   [case] study on selected insect species.
FT Untersuchung der Verteilungsmuster von Tierpopulationen am Beispiel
   ausgewaehlter Insektenarten.
AU Sturm, Robert (Robert.Sturm@sbg.ac.at) 
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 120
IS 3
PS 117-121
PD Juni 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB With the help of mathematical methods the distribution patterns of four
   insects (Corylobium avellanae (SCHRANK, 1801), Phenacoccus sp.
   COCKERELL, 1893, Brachypterus urticae (FABRICIUS, 1792), Palomena
   prasina (LINNAEUS, 1761)) on their preferential habitat plants (common
   hazel, Chaerophyllum, nettle, thuja) were subjected to a detailed
   analysis. Based upon the statistical evaluation of the counting data (n
   = 100) the aphids and the sap beetles living on the upper leafs of the
   nettle are commonly characterised by a contagious distribution of single
   individuals, whereby according to the mode of calculation the grade of
   individual aggregation may be described as intermediate to high. A
   completely different behaviour with regards to the distribution of
   single individuals may be stated for those sap beetles occupying the
   lower leafs of the nettle as well as the green shield bugs, which both
   increasingly tend to a regular individual distribution. The mealybugs
   are marked by a mainly random distribution of their individuals.
C1 Sturm, Robert; Brunnleitenweg 41, A-5061 Elsbethen, Austria, Austria.
EM Robert.Sturm@sbg.ac.at
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology;
   Parasitology
SN 0013-8843
BD Nutrition; Diet; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Ecology;
   Habitat utilization
DE Brachypterus urticae; Palomena prasina [Food plants /  / mathematical
   modelling] [Distribution within habitat / Dispersion pattern / ]
   [Habitat preference /  / ]. 
   Corylobium avellanae; Phenacoccus [Plant hosts /  / mathematical
   modelling] [Distribution within habitat / Dispersion pattern / ]
   [Habitat preference /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cucujoidea,
   Nitidulidae, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Pentatomomorpha, Pentatomoidea,
   Pentatomidae, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha, Aphidoidea, Coccoidea
OR Brachypterus urticae (Nitidulidae). 
   Palomena prasina (Pentatomidae). 
   Corylobium avellanae (Aphidoidea): [Parasite]. 
   Phenacoccus (Coccoidea): [Parasite].

DT Article
TI Contributions to the knowledge of the Oriental Psychidae III. The
   species of Struthisca Meyrick, 1905 and Taleporia Huebner, 1825 in
   southeast Asia (Lepidoptera: Psychidae).
FT Beitraege zur Kenntnis der orientalischen Psychidae III. Die
   suedostasiatischen Arten von Struthisca Meyrick, 1905 and Taleporia
   Huebner, 1825 (Lepidoptera: Psychidae).
AU Sobczyk, Thomas (ThomasSobczyk@aol.com) 
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 120
IS 3
PS 133-141
PD Juni 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this third contribution to the oriental Psychidae, the genera
   Struthisca MEYRICK, 1905 and Taleporia HUBNER, 1825 are studied. Both
   genera were previously unknown from Southeast Asia. Struthisca MEYRICK,
   1905 stat. rev. is considered a valid genus and not a synonym of
   Ctenocompa MEYRICK, 1893. The following species are described:
   Struthisca silaceategula sp. nov., Struthisca brunneotegula sp. nov.,
   Struthisca suasa sp. nov., Taleporia inopinata sp. nov. and Taleporia
   reticulata sp. nov. Taleporia subaenea (MEYRICK, 1921) comb. nov. and
   Taleporia epomias (MEYRICK, 1921) comb. nov. are transferred from
   Narycia STEPHENS, 1833 to Taleporia HUBNER, 1825 and the first time
   figured. Two further species from Java are figured and characterized but
   not described.
C1 Sobczyk, Thomas; Diesterwegstrasse 28, D-02977 Hoyerswerda, Germany,
   Germany.

DT Article
TI Scorpions of Iran (Arachnida: Scorpiones). Part VI. Lorestan Province.
AU Navidpour, Sharokh
   Nayebzadeh, Hassan H.
   Soleglad, Michael E.
   Fet, Victor
   Kovarik, Frantisek
   Kayedi, Mohammad Hassan
SO Euscorpius
VL 99
PS 1-23
PD June 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2010_99.pdf
AW http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2010_99.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ten species of scorpions belonging to three families are reported from
   the Lorestan Province of Iran. Of these, five species are recorded from
   the province for the first time: Hottentotta zagrosensis Kovarik, 1997;
   Mesobuthus eupeus phillipsii (Pocock, 1889); Orthochirus iranus Kovarik,
   2004; Razianus zarudnyi (Birula, 1903); and Scorpio maurus townsendi
   (Pocock, 1900). One new species is described, Hottentotta lorestanus sp.
   n.; it can be easily distinguished from the other four species of the
   genus known from Iran by its coloration; it is the only Iranian species
   which has the entire pedipalps yellow and the metasomal segments I to IV
   greenish gray. Also presented is a key to all species of scorpions found
   in the province.
C1 Navidpour, Sharokh; Razi Reference Laboratory of Scorpion Research, Razi
   Vaccine and Serum Research Institute, P.O. Box 31975/148, Department of
   Venomous Animals & Toxins, Hesarak, Karaj, Iran, Iran.

   iranus; Razianus zarudnyi; Scorpio maurus townsendi [Iran / Lorestan
   Province / New record].

DT Article
TI A new species of scorpion of the genus Buthoscorpio Werner, 1936
   (Scorpiones: Buthidae) from Andhra Pradesh, India.
AU Javed, S.M. Maqsood (javedwwf2007@gmail.com) 
   Rao, K. Thulsi
   Mirza, Zeeshan A.
   Sanap, Rajesh V.
   Tampal, Farida
SO Euscorpius
VL 98
PS 1-11
PD June 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2010_98.pdf
AW http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2010_98.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of scorpion, Buthoscorpio rayalensis sp. nov., is
   described from Andhra Pradesh, India. The new species of scorpion can be
   differentiated from its congeners in having the following set of
   morphological characters: anterior edge of carapace exhibiting very
   broad subtle indentation with a conspicuous epistome present medially,
   median eyes situated anteriorly in the ratio 1:3.1, interocular area
   smooth, patella anteriorly smooth and rounded, mesosomal tergites
   smooth, pectines 17[long dash]17, and arrangement of lateral eyes.
   Stenochirus jinnahii Amir, Kama-luddin et Jabbar, 2005 and S. rahmatii
   Amir, Kamaluddin et Jabbar, 2005 are considered Buthidae incertae sedis
   as their generic allocation has been erroneous.
C1 Javed, S.M. Maqsood; World Wide Fund for Nature-India (WWF), APSO, 818,
   Castle Hills, Road No. 2, Near NMDC, Vijayanagar Colony,
   Hyderabad-500057, Andhra Pradesh, India, India.
EM javedwwf2007@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1536-9307

   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
