AN ZOOR14703019802
DT Article
TI New Late Paleozoic brachiopods and molluscs.
AU Waterhouse, J.B.
SO Earthwise
VL 9
PS 1-134
PD 12 May 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New taxa are proposed, including brachiopod genera Austrothaerus, type
   species Aulosteges (Taeniothaerus) randsi Hill, 1950 and Lakismatia,
   type species Taeniothaerus lakismakos Briggs, 1986 as a subgenus of
   Taeniothaerus Whitehouse (Family Aulostegidae), Guadaluposteges, type
   species Strophalosia guadalupensis Shumard, 1860 and Shuzhongia, type
   species Taeniothaerus densipustulatus Shen et al. 2000 (Family
   Rhamnariidae), Kadelia, type species Inflatia dakielis McKellar, 1965
   (Family Dictyoclostidae), Barringtonia, type species Fluctuaria
   magnificans Campbell & McKelvey, 1972 and Calytrixia, type species
   Terrakea capillata Waterhouse in Foster & Waterhouse, 1988 (Family
   Proboscidellidae), Keoghalosia, type species K. onegumensis n. sp.,
   Cicatricia, type species Strophalosia hystricula Girty, 1909,
   Crenalosia, type species Heteralosia paucispinosa Cooper & Grant, 1975,
   Glabauria, type species Echinalosia runnegari Briggs, 1998 as subgenus
   of Echinalosia Waterhouse, and Nothalosina, type species E. voiseyi
   Briggs, 1998 (Family Strophalosiidae), Aphaurorhynchia, type species
   Plekonella iniquitas Waterhouse (Family Wellerellidae), Attenuocurvus,
   type species Attenuatella incurvata Waterhouse, 1964 (Family
   Ambocoeliidae), Globosospiniger, type species Pustuloplica cooperi
   Waterhouse, 1981 (Family Martiniidae), and Tweedaleia, type species T.
   tweedalei n. sp. (Family Ingelarellidae). New bivalve genera are:
   Yanceyopsis, type species Quadratonucula stella Yancey, 1978 (Family
   Nuculopsidae), Obliquomallus, type species Quadratonucula argentinensis
   Gonzalez, 1972 (Family Malletiidae), Hillaepecten, type species H.
   queenslandica n. sp. (Family Heteropectinidae), Plicocuneus, type
   species P. rhylstonensis n. sp. (Family Kalenteridae), Melicusia, type
   species M. jelli n. sp. (Family Cypricardiniidae) and Dundulomya, type
   species Myonia parallela Dun, 1932 (Family ?Vacunellidae), and new
   gastropod genus Fletcherispira, type species Platyschisma rotundatum
   Morris, 1845 (Subfamily Turbonellinae). Newly described species are
   Costatumulus randsi Balfe & Waterhouse, Platycancrinella kletsi n. sp.,
   Acanthalosia mysteriosa n. sp., Gilledia inornata n. sp., and Megadesmus
   ponderosus n. sp. Revised genera and species include Fluctuaria (now
   Xanthoserella?) campbelli Roberts, Linoproductus (Balakhonia)
   rawdonvalensis Peou & Engel and L. (Linoproductus) kerripitensis Peou &
   Engel (both now Papiliolinus), Acanthalosia? parfreyi Waterhouse (now
   Wyndhamia), Strophalosia jukesi concava Maxwell (now Acanthalosia),
   Plekonina spissatella Waterhouse, Wairakiella rostrata Waterhouse,
   Aperispirifer crassicostatus Waterhouse (now Kaninospirifer), Hoskingia
   Campbell, Sokelasma Smirnova and Praeamonotis anticipata Waterhouse.
   Class Articulata (Brachiopoda) is subdivided into superorders
   Strophomeniformi, Productiformi, Pentameriformi, Spiriferiformi,
   Rhynchonelliformi and Terebratuliformi. Three infrasuborders are
   proposed within Suborder Productidina, namely Productellimorphi (for
   superfamilies Productelloidea, Marginiferoidea, Echinoconchidae and
   Horridonioidea), Aulostegimorphi (for superfamily Aulostegoidea,
   Institelloidea, and Scacchinelloidea) and Productimorphi (for
   superfamilies Productoidea and Linoproductoidea). Richthofeniidina is
   proposed as a new suborder in Productida. Cooperinidina is proposed as a
   subordinal subdivision of Lyttoniida Williams. New suborder Martiniidina
   is proposed for superfamilies Ambocoelioidea George, Brachythyridoidea
   Fredericks, Martinioidea Waagen and Ingelarelloidea Campbell, and new
   subfamily units Attenuocurvinae and Crurithyrinae within Ambocoeliidae.
   New subfamily Plekonellinae based on Plekonella Campbell, 1953, is
   proposed within Wellerellidae. Classification for Dielasmatoidea
   (Brachiopoda) is rearranged to demonstrate relationships, and three new
   tribes, Fletcherithyrini, Plectelasmini and Hoskingiini are proposed
   within the superfamily
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1176-1555
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Type species; Type
   material; Diagnosis; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Available name;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Australasian region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Australasia;
   Australia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

PT J
AN ZOOR14607049504
DT Article
TI Glishades ericksoni, a new hadrosauroid (Dinosauria: Ornithopoda) from
   the Late Cretaceous of North America.
AU Prieto-Marquez, Albert (redshore@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2452
PS 1-17
PD 12 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2452.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02452p017.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus and species of hadrosauroid dinosaur, Glishades ericksoni,
   is described based on paired partial premaxillae collected from the
   Upper Cretaceous Two Medicine Formation of Montana, in the Western
   Interior of the United States of America. This taxon is diagnosed on the
   basis of a unique combination of characters: absence of everted oral
   margin, arcuate oral margin with wide and straight, obliquely oriented,
   and undeflected anterolateral corner, grooved transversal thickening on
   ventral surface of premaxilla posterior to denticulate oral margin, and
   foramina on anteromedial surface above oral edge and adjacent to
   proximal end of narial bar. Maximum parsimony analysis positioned G.
   ericksoni as a derived hadrosauroid. Exclusion of G. ericksoni from
   Hadrosauridae was unambiguously supported by the lack in AMNH 27414 of a
   dorsomedially reflected premaxillary oral margin. Furthermore, the
   maximum agreement subtree positioned G. ericksoni as the sister taxon to
   Bactrosaurus johnsoni. This position was unambiguously supported by
   posteroventral thickening on the ventral surface of the premaxilla
   (independently derived in saurolophid hadrosaurids and Ouranosaurus
   nigeriensis) and having foramina on each premaxilla on the anterior
   surface, adjacent to the parasagittal plane of the rostrum
   (reconstructed as independently derived in Brachylophosaurus canadensis,
   Maiasaura peeblesorum, and Edmontosaurus annectens).
C1 Prieto-Marquez, Albert; Division of Paleontology, American Museum of
   Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, New York, NY 10024,
   USA, USA.
EM redshore@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Skeleton; Skull; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America;
   USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Glishades [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Glishades ericksoni [Montana /  / New species]. 
   Hadrosauroidea [Jaws / Premaxilla morphology / ] [Phylogeny / Cladistics
   / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Ornithischia,
   Ornithopoda
OR Glishades (Ornithopoda): [Gen nov, Of Hadrosauroidea, Type species
   Glishades ericksoni, p. 3, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Glishades ericksoni (Ornithopoda): [Sp nov, Montana, P. 3; Fossil]. 
   Hadrosauroidea (Ornithopoda): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14607049504
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14607049506
DT Article
TI A new species of Gamasiphis (Acari: Ologamasidae) from Brazil, with a
   key to species from the Neotropical Region.
AU Castilho, Raphael C. (raphael.campos@bol.com.br) 
   De Moraes, Gilberto J.
   Narita, Joao P.Z.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2452
PS 31-43
PD 12 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2452.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02452p043.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Gamasiphis paulista n. sp. is described based on specimens representing
   all postembryonic stages, collected from litter and soil in Piracicaba,
   State of Sao Paulo. This is the first species of Gamasiphis described
   from Brazil. A key is provided for the separation of species of this
   genus known from the Neotropical Region.
C1 Castilho, Raphael C.; Departamento de Entomologia e Acarologia, Escola
   Superior de Agricultura "Luiz de Queiroz" (ESALQ), Universidade de Sao
   Paulo, 13418-900, Piracicaba, Sao Paulo, Brazil, Brazil.
EM raphael.campos@bol.com.br
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Gamasiphis [Neotropical region /  / Key to species]. 
   Gamasiphis paulista [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Gamasiphis - Berlese (Acari): [Key to species, Neotropical region, P.
   41]. 
   Gamasiphis paulista (Acari): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 32].

DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14607049507
DT Article
TI A new genus and three new species of Nothopodinae (Acari: Eriophyidae)
   from Guangxi, China.
AU Li, De-Wei
   Wang, Guo-Quan
   Wei, Sui-Gai (weisuigai@tom.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2452
PS 44-50
PD 12 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2452.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02452p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and three new species of eriophyid mites from Guangxi Zhuang
   Autonomous Region, South China are described and illustrated: Calliparus
   lanceolarus n. gen., n. sp. infesting Glochidion lanceolarium (Roxb.)
   Voigt (Euphorbiaceae); Colopodacus glochidion n. sp. infesting
   Glochidion sp. (Euphorbiaceae) and Neocosella laurifolia n. sp.
   infesting Genianthus laurifolius (Roxb.) Hook.f. (Asclepiadaceae). All
   species described here are vagrants on the undersurface of host leaves.
C1 Wei, Sui-Gai; Department of Plant Protection, Guangxi University,
   Nanning, Guangxi 530004, China, China.
EM weisuigai@tom.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Associations; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Calliparus lanceolarus [Associations / Glochidion lanceolarium (Plant) /
   New associate species] [Guangxi Zhuang /  / New species; plant
   associate]. 
   Colopodacus glochidion [Associations / Glochidion (Plant) / New
   associate species] [Guangxi Zhuang /  / New species; plant associate]. 
   Neocosella laurifolia [Associations / Genianthus laurifolius (Plant) /
   New associate species] [Guangxi Zhuang /  / New species; plant
   associate]. 
   Nothopodinae [Guangxi Zhuang /  / Key to species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Calliparus (Acari): [Gen nov, Of tribe Colopodacini, Type species
   Calliparus lanceolarus, p. 45].

TI A new species of Simpsonichthys (Cyprinodontiformes: Rivulidae) from the
   rio Sao Francisco basin, northeastern Brazil.
AU Bressane Nielsen, Dalton Tavares (dnielsen@uol.com.br) 
   Shibatta, Oscar Akio
   Dos Reis Suzart, Rogerio
   Faour Martin, Amer
SO Zootaxa
VL 2452
PS 51-58
PD 12 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2452.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02452p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Simpsonichtys lopesi n. sp. is described from a temporary pool located
   in the Sao Francisco river basin. This species is distinguished from
   remaining species, except S. adornatus, by the large number of dorsal
   fin rays, which makes possible a large dorsal fin base length that
   begins well anterior to the middle of the body, before the vertical line
   through the pelvic fin. This species differs from S. adornatus by the
   color pattern of the anal fin, which may have yellow stripes or light
   dots (vs. small light points), and also by the lower number of dorsal
   fin rays.
C1 Bressane Nielsen, Dalton Tavares; Av. Independencia, 531, ap. 21-B,
   12031-000, Taubate, Brazil, Brazil.

TI Scale insects (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha: Coccoidea) of the Krakatau
   Islands including species from adjacent Java.

AB In this paper we provide a list of all species of scale insects that
   have been collected in the Krakatau Islands since the catastrophic
   eruption of 1883. Included in the list are species collected during the
   La Trobe University Expedition in 1984 from the islands and from the
   adjacent mainland in Java and also species collected in earlier
   expeditions, including those during 1919[long dash]1933, discussed by
   Dammerman (1948). In addition, we describe two new species of armoured
   scales, Aulacaspis thorntoni Williams & Miller and Greeniella calophylli
   Williams & Miller and provide a key to the species of Greeniella
   Cockerell.

PT J
AN ZOOR14607049391
DT Article
TI An abelisauroid dinosaur with a non-atrophied manus from the Late
   Cretaceous Pari Aike Formation of southern Patagonia.
AU Ezcurra, Martin D. (martindezcurra@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Agnolin, Federico L.
   Novas, Fernando E.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2450
PS 1-25
PD 10 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2450.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02450p025.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We describe the new basal abelisauroid dinosaur Austrocheirus isasii
   gen. et sp. nov. from the Late Cretaceous Pari Aike Formation of
   southwestern Patagonia, Argentina. The preserved remains include manual
   bones, a distal tibia, and some pedal and axial elements. Austrocheirus
   is differentiated from other basal theropods by the presence of
   metacarpal III with a dorsoventrally compressed shaft and posteriorly
   displaced collateral tendon fossae located at the same level of the
   proximal end of distal condyles, and pedal phalanges with a conspicuous
   longitudinal crest delimitating the dorsal margin of the distal
   collateral tendon fossae. A cladistic analysis recovered the new species
   as more derived than Ceratosaurus and Berberosaurus, but within a
   polytomy at the base of Abelisauroidea, an assignment supported by two
   abelisauroid synapomorphies: distal end of tibia with a planar vertical
   scar for the reception of the ascending process of the astragalus that
   occupies most of its anterior surface and is medially bounded by the
   longitudinally oriented facet; and scar for the reception of the
   ascending process with a median vertical ridge, which imbeds into a
   crescentic vertical groove on the posterior surface of the ascending
   process of the astragalus forming an interlocking tibiotarsal
   articulation. Furthermore, Austrocheirus represents the first known
   medium-sized Late Cretaceous abelisauroid bearing nonatrophied hands.
   The evidence provided here suggests that the strong reduction of the
   forelimb recorded in derived abelisaurids is not directly correlated
   with their increased body-size, but it seems to be an evolutionary event
   exclusive to this lineage within Ceratosauria.
C1 Ezcurra, Martin D.; Laboratorio de Anatomia Comparada y Evolucion de los
   Vertebrados, Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales "Bernardino
   Rivadavia", Avenida Angel Gallardo 470 (C1405DJR), Buenos Aires,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM martindezcurra@yahoo.com.ar
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Evolution; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America; Geological
   time periods; Mesozoic
DE Austrocheirus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Austrocheirus isasii [Argentina /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Ceratosauria [Skeleton / Skeletal characters / taxonomic implications]
   [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic relationships of genera / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Theropoda
OR Austrocheirus (Theropoda): [Gen nov, Of Abelisauroidea, Type species
   Austrocheirus isasii, p. 3, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Austrocheirus isasii (Theropoda): [Sp nov, Argentina, Cretaceous, P. 3;
   Fossil]. 
   Ceratosauria (Theropoda): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14607049391
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14607049393
DT Article
TI A new species of the rare caridean genus Bresilia Calman (Crustacea:
   Decapoda: Bresiliidae) from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan, representing a
   family new to the North Pacific marine fauna.
AU Komai, Tomoyuki (komai@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
   Yamada, Yusuke
SO Zootaxa
VL 2450
PS 41-52
PD 10 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2450.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02450p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the rare caridean genus Bresilia Calman, 1896, B.
   gibbosa, is described and illustrated on the basis of one ovigerous
   female and one male specimens collected from a shallow water marine cave
   in Okinawa Island, Ryukyu Islands, Japan. The new species is
   morphologically similar to B. antipodarum Bruce, 1990, B. briankensleyi
   Bruce, 2005, B. plumifera Bruce, 1990 and B. saldanhai Calado,
   Chevaldonne & dos Santos, 2004 in the strongly produced third abdominal
   tergite, the presence of a long epistomal process, and the presence of
   an exopodal flagellum on the first maxilliped, but is easily
   distinguished from all these allied species by the possession of movable
   spines in the dorsal rostral series and the angular, instead of spinose,
   pterygostomial margin of the carapace. This new species is the first
   representative of Bresiliidae from the North Pacific Ocean.
C1 Komai, Tomoyuki; Natural History Museum and Institute, Chiba, 955-2
   Aoba-cho, Chuo-ku, Chiba, 260-8682, Japan, Japan.
EM komai@chiba-muse.or.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Bresilia gibbosa [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
   Bresiliidae [North Pacific /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Natantia
OR Bresilia antipodarum species group (Natantia): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, Species, p. 50]. 
   Bresilia gibbosa (Natantia): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 42]. 
   Bresiliidae (Natantia): [New record].

DT Article
TI A taxonomic guide to the Echinodermata of the South Atlantic Bight, USA:
   1. Sea cucumbers (Echinodermata: Holothuroidea).
AU Pawson, David L. (pawsond@si.edu) 
   Pawson, Doris J.
   King, Rachael A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2449
PS 1-48
PD 7 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2449.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02449p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A summary account is given of the 33 holothurian species known from the
   South Atlantic Bight, from Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, to Cape
   Canaveral, Florida, from the shore to a depth of 200 meters. Four of the
   six known orders of holothurians are represented in the study area. Each
   species is diagnosed and illustrated; citations of informative
   literature and brief discussions of distribution and general biology are
   included. Also included are dichotomous keys to aid in identification to
   the species level. A new genus is erected to accommodate
   Pseudocolochirus mysticus Deichmann, 1930. Ocnus pygmaeus (Theel, 1886b)
   and O. surinamensis (Semper, 1868) are referred to the genus Aslia Rowe,
   1970.
C1 Pawson, David L.; National Museum of Natural History, Mail Stop MRC 163,
   Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC 20013-7012, USA, USA.

TI A new genus and species of Western Atlantic sea lily in the family
   Septocrinidae (Echinodermata: Crinoidea: Bourgueticrinida).
AU Mironov, Alexandr N. (miron@ocean.ru) 
   Pawson, David L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2449
PS 49-68
PD 7 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2449.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02449p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Rouxicrinus vestitus new genus, new species, collected during
   submersible dives at depths of 421-887 m near Barbados, Colombia and the
   Bahamas is described, and notes on ecology are included. It is referred
   to the family Septocrinidae Mironov, 2000, which now comprises three
   genera, Zeuctocrinus A.M. Clark, 1973, Septocrinus Mironov, 2000, and
   Rouxicrinus new genus. This new genus differs significantly from both
   Septocrinus and Zeuctocrinus in having numerous low columnals in the
   proxistele, which tapers toward the crown, first pinnule arising more
   proximally, thorns on brachials and pinnulars, and a thick covering of
   soft tissue on arms and pinnules.
C1 Mironov, Alexandr N.; P.P. Shirshov Institute of Oceanology, Russian
   Academy of Sciences, Nakhimovskyi Prospekt 36, Moscow 117997, Russia,
   Russia.
EM miron@ocean.ru

   Ocean; North Atlantic

   Barbados / ] [ / Colombia / ].

TI Review of the Barcinus-complex with description of new taxa (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera: Aradidae).
AU Heiss, E. (aradus@aon.at) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2448
PS 1-25
PD 7 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2448.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02448p025.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with the revision of the flat bug genus Barcinus Stal
   1873 recorded from the Oriental-Papuan Region. Newly available
   additional material and biogeographical considerations allowed the
   distinction of discrete species groups, which-in addition to the type
   genus Barcinus-are defined and proposed as Heterobarcinus n. gen.,
   Papuabarcinus n. gen. and Brachybarcinus n. gen. The genus Barcinus
   remains monotypic, with the species horridus Stal 1873. To
   Heterobarcinus n. gen. is assigned the species bhoutanensis (Usinger &
   Matsuda 1959), kormilevi (Bai, Heiss & Cai 2006), schaeferi n. sp.
   (China, Fujian) and minor n. sp. (China, Yunnan). The genus
   Papuabarcinus n. gen. contains the species ceramensis (Usinger & Matsuda
   1959), laminiferus (Walker 1873), papuensis (Usinger & Matsuda 1959),
   productus (Usinger & Matsuda 1959), truncatus (Kormilev 1955), riedeli
   n. sp. and intermedius n. sp. (both from Irian Jaya). For vietnamensis
   n. sp. (Vietnam, Southern China), secundus n. sp. (China, Fujian,
   Guangxi) and baianus n. sp. (China Yunnan) the new genus Brachybarcinus
   n. gen. is erected. All species are illustrated and are keyed.
C1 Heiss, E.; Tiroler Landesmuseum, Josef Schaffl Strasse 2a, A-6020
   Innsbruck, Austria, Austria.
EM aradus@aon.at
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

DT Article
TI Two new species of phlebotomine sand flies (Diptera: Psychodidae,
   Phlebotominae) from Quintana Roo, Mexico.
AU Ibanez-Bernal, Sergio (sergio.ibanez@inecol.edu.mx) 
   May-Uc, Emigdio
   Rebollar-Tellez, Eduardo A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2448
PS 26-34
PD 7 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2448.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02448p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of phlebotomine sand flies from Quintana Roo, Mexico are
   described and illustrated following the classification proposal of
   Galati (2003). Pintomyia (Pifanomyia) itza Ibanez-Bernal, May-Uc and
   Rebollar-Tellez sp. nov., is described based on four male specimens,
   whereas Psathyromyia (Psathyromyia) maya Ibanez-Bernal, May-Uc and
   Rebollar-Tellez sp. nov., is described based on seven female specimens.
   Pintomyia (Pif.) itza clearly belongs to the verrucarum series, and is
   the only species of this series known to occur outside South America.
   Psathyromyia (Psa.) maya belongs to the lanei series which was
   previously known only from Brazil and Paraguay.
C1 Ibanez-Bernal, Sergio; Instituto de Ecologia, A.C. Red Ambiente y
   Sustentabilidad, Carretera antigua a Coatepec No. 351, El Haya, Xalapa,
   C.P. 91070, Veracruz, Mexico, Mexico.
EM sergio.ibanez@inecol.edu.mx
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   America

   New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

TI Nomenclatural changes in North American Phymatodes Mulsant (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae).
AU Swift, Ian P. (ian@plecoma.com) 
   Ray, Ann M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2448
PS 35-52
PD 7 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2448.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02448p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The following nomenclatural changes to the genus Phymatodes Mulsant,
   1839 are proposed: P. juglandis Leng, 1890 = P. decussatus (LeConte,
   1857); P. mohavensis Linsley and Chemsak, 1963 = P. nitidus LeConte,
   1874; P. lecontei Linsley, 1938 (a replacement name) = P. grandis Casey,
   1912; P. oregonensis Chemsak, 1963 = P. nigrescens Hardy and Preece,
   1927; P. blandus picipes Linsley, 1934 and P. blandus propinquus
   Linsley, 1934 = P. blandus (LeConte, 1859); P. hirtellus densipennis
   Casey, 1912 and P. ur s ae Knull, 1940 = P. hirtellus (LeConte, 1873);
   P. decussatus australis Chemsak, 1963 and P. decussatus posticus Van
   Dyke, 1920 = P. obliquus Casey, 1891; P. f ros t i Casey, 1924, a valid
   name which has not previously been mentioned in the literature = P.
   dimidiatus (Kirby in Richardson, 1837); P. concolor Linsley, 1934 is
   afforded full species status; P. lividus (Rossi, 1794) is formally
   recorded as established in North America. A key and diagnoses for all
   native and introduced North American species are provided, which include
   the more recently described species, P. tysoni Linsley and Chemsak,
   1984, and P. shareeae Cope, 1984, in addition to the introduced species
   P. lividus.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Seira (Collembola, Entomobryidae) from Brazilian
   coast.
AU Bellini, Bruno Cavalcante (entobellini@yahoo.com.br) 
   Fernandes, Liliane Henriques
   Zeppelini, Douglas
SO Zootaxa
VL 2448
PS 53-60
PD 7 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2448.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02448p060.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Seira Lubbock (Entomobryidae), S. praiana sp. nov.
   and S. potiguara sp. nov., are described and illustrated. Both species
   were collected on Brazilian coast. S. praiana sp. nov. has some
   similarities with S. americana Jacquemart and S. nunezae Christiansen &
   Bellinger while S. potiguara sp. nov. resembles S. brasiliana (Arle) and
   S. proannulata (Bonet) in some aspects of the dorsal distribution of the
   macrochaetae. Seira is a very specious genus in Brazil, and with the
   addition of S. praiana sp. nov. and S. potiguara sp. nov., the number of
   recorded species for the country increase to 24.
C1 Bellini, Bruno Cavalcante; Departamento de Sistematica e Ecologia,
   Centro de Ciencias Exatas e da Natureza, Laboratorio de Invertebrados
   Paulo Young, Universidade Federal da Paraiba-Campus I, 58059-900, Joao
   Pessoa, PB, Brazil, Brazil.

   species.

PS 61-68

U2 0
AB A new planthopper genus, Mucillnata, is established with a new species,
   Mucillnata rava sp. nov. as the type species, in the tribe
   Tropidocephalini, subfamily Delphacinae from southern China. A key to
   the known genera of the tribe from China is also provided and the
   differences between the new genus and closely related genera are
   discussed.

AN ZOOR14607049058
DT Article
TI The nomenclatural status of the nomina of amphibians and reptiles
   created by Garsault (1764), with a parsimonious solution to an old
   nomenclatural problem regarding the genus Bufo (Amphibia, Anura),
   comments on the taxonomy of this genus, and comments on some nomina
   created by Laurenti (1768).
AU Dubois, Alain (adubois@mnhn.fr) 
   Bour, Roger
SO Zootaxa
VL 2447
PS 1-52
PD 6 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2447.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02447p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The nomenclatural consequences of the recent rediscovery of the works of
   Garsault (1764, 1765, 1767) in amphibians and reptiles are examined in
   detail. The 13 new nomina of these two groups created by Garsault (1764)
   distribute in three categories: (1) three of these nomina (Lacertus,
   Rana viridis, Testudo marina) cause no problem, being just junior
   synonyms of senior nomina created by Linnaeus (1758); (2) four of them
   (Bufo, Salamandra, Scincus, Vipera) become the valid nomina of taxa, in
   replacement of identical nomina created later by Laurenti (1768), thus
   entailing no change in the nomina of their included species and
   subspecies but changes in their complete nominal-complexes (including
   their authors and dates); (3) six of these nomina are here rejected as
   invalid senior synonyms (Ranetta, Serpens, Lacertus aquatilis, Lacertus
   terrestris) or homonyms (Lacertus viridis, Testudo terrestris) of nomina
   in current use, by virtue of Article 23.9.1 of the Code. A very positive
   result of the rediscovery of these works is that it allows to solve for
   the best an old nomenclatural problem, concerning the nucleospecies
   (type-species) of the genus Bufo: whereas the nucleospecies
   (type-species) of Bufo Laurenti, 1768 is Bufo viridis Laurenti, 1768, we
   hereby designate Rana bufo Linnaeus, 1758 as nucleospecies of Bufo
   Garsault, 1764. This case shows that it is sometimes possible, even in
   complex nomenclatural situations, to solve them through a proper use of
   the Rules of the Code, without having to appeal to the ICZN for the use
   of its Plenary-Powers. From a taxonomic point of view, we think the data
   published so far do not allow currently to stabilise the generic
   taxonomy of the BUFONIDAE. Pending additional data, we support a
   conservative attitude, maintaining in the genus Bufo most species
   traditionally referred to this genus. In particular, we think all
   Eurasian species of this family, which include several pairs of species
   known to be able to produce viable adult hybrids, should be kept in this
   genus, but in three distinct subgenera: Bufo Garsault, 1764 for the
   group including Bufo bufo (Linnaeus, 1758); Bufotes Rafinesque, 1815 for
   the group including Bufo viridis (Laurenti, 1768); and Epidalea Cope,
   1864 for the group including Bufo calamita (Laurenti, 1768). This survey
   also allows to discuss the appropriateness of the current Article 11.9.5
   dealing with specific trinomina, especially as they appear in Laurenti
   (1768), and to point again to the need to implement more drastic Rules
   regarding the conditions required for a nomen being compliant for
   protection through Article 23.9.1 of the Code.
C1 Dubois, Alain; Reptiles & Amphibiens, UMR 7205 OSEB, Departement
   Systematique & Evolution, Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, CP 30,
   25 rue Cuvier, 75505 Paris, France, France.
EM adubois@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type species; Synonymy; Available name;
   Taxonomy; Geological time periods
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Bufonidae, Hylidae, Ranidae, Caudata, Salamandridae, Reptilia, Anapsida,
   Testudines, Cryptodira, Testudinidae, Lepidosauria, Squamata, Sauria,
   Lacertidae, Scincidae, Serpentes, Boidae, Colubridae, Elapidae,
   Viperidae
OR Animalia: [International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, Proposed
   emendation with regard to availability of specific nomina, p. 9]. 
   Amphibia (Vertebrata): [Systematics, Names created by Garsault 1764 &
   Laurenti 1768, p. 6]. 
   Amphibies - Garsault 1764 (Vertebrata): [Included taxa, Amphibia &
   Reptilia, p. 32]. 
   Reptilia (Vertebrata): [Systematics, Names created by Garsault 1764 &
   Laurenti 1768, p. 6]. 
   Bufo - Garsault 1764 (Bufonidae): [Type species, Designated Rana bufo
   Linnaeus 1758, p. 21, Cited by author as Nucleospecies designation]. 
   Bufo (Bufo) - Garsault 1764 (Bufonidae): [Syn nov, Bufavus Portis 1885,
   p. 24, Cited by author as New invalid junior doxisonym; Syn nov, Pegaeus

   doxisonym; Syn nov, Platosphus de l'Isle 1877, p. 24, Cited by author as

   Bufo (Bufotes) - Rafinesque 1815 (Bufonidae): [Syn nov, Batrachus

   Bufo (Epidalea) - Cope 1864 (Bufonidae): [Syn nov, Calamitus Rafinesque

   Bufo calamita - Laurenti 1768 (Bufonidae): [Designated type species for,
   Calamitus Rafinesque 1815, p. 22]. 
   Bufo gessneri - (Tschudi 1838) (Bufonidae): [Taxonomic position,
   Incertae sedis, p. 22]. 
   Bufo priscus - Spinar, Klembara & Meszaros 1993 (Bufonidae): [Taxonomic
   position, Incertae sedis, p. 22]. 
   Calamitus - Rafinesque 1815 (Bufonidae): [Type species, Designated Bufo
   calamita Laurenti 1768, p. 22]. 
   Torrentophryne - Rao & Yang 1994 (Bufonidae): [Type species, Designated
   Torrentophryne aspinia Rao & Yang 1994, p. 24, Cited by author as
   Nucleospecies designation]. 
   Torrentophryne aspinia - Rao & Yang 1994 (Bufonidae): [Designated type
   species for, Torrentophryne Rao & Yang 1994, p. 24, Cited by author as
   Nucleospecies designation]. 
   Hyla - Laurenti 1768 (Hylidae): [Senior synonym, Of Ranetta Garsault
   1764, p. 28, Cited by author as Invalid senior doxisonym]. 
   Ranella - Garsault 1764 (Hylidae): [Spelling, P. 28]. 
   Ranetta - Garsault 1764 (Hylidae): [Junior synonym, Of Hyla Laurenti
   1768, p. 28, Cited by author as Invalid senior doxisonym; Spelling, P.

DT Article
TI The smallest terrestrial vertebrate of Ecuador: a new frog ot the genus
   Pristimantis (Amphibia: Strabomantidae) from the Cordillera del Condor.
AU Teran-Valdez, Andrea (andreateran84@gmail.com) 
   Guayasamin, Juan M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2447
PS 53-68
PD 6 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2447.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02447p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe a new species of Pristimantis characterized by its
   diminutive size (maximum SVL in males 13.7 mm; n = 46), dorsum smooth to
   slightly shagreen, finger and toe pads expanded, and red iris with thin
   black reticulation. The species is the smallest terrestrial vertebrate
   recorded in Ecuador, and the smallest species in the diverse genus
   Pristimantis. The osteological traits of the new species are similar to
   those found in other Pristimantis species, and no elements are lost
   because of miniaturization. The new species is only known from two close
   localities in Cordillera del Condor, Provincia Zamora Chinchipe,
   Ecuador.
C1 Teran-Valdez, Andrea; Museo de Zoologia, Escuela de Ciencias Biologicas,
   Pontificia Universidad Catolica del Ecuador, Av. 12 de Octubre y Roca,
   Aptdo. 17-01-2184, Quito, Ecuador, Ecuador.
EM andreateran84@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   South America
DE Pristimantis minimus [Ecuador /  / New species].

ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Leptodactylidae

PT J
AN ZOOR14607049060
DT Article
TI Unravelling the underestimated diversity of Philippine water monitor
   lizards (Squamata: Varanus salvator complex), with the description of
   two new species and a new subspecies.
AU Koch, Andre (andrepascalkoch@web.de) 
   Gaulke, Maren
   Boehme, Wolfgang
SO Zootaxa
VL 2446
PS 1-54
PD 6 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2446.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02446p054.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Recently, the first part of the morphological revision of the Southeast
   Asian water monitor lizards of the Varanus salvator (Laurenti, 1768)
   species group provided a taxonomic overview over the members of this
   successful and widespread species complex (Koch et al. 2007). There, the
   Philippine taxa marmoratus, nuchalis and cumingi were re-elevated to
   species status due to diagnostic morphological characteristics, e.g.
   significantly enlarged scales on the neck region. In this second part of
   the ongoing revision, these three species are re-investigated using
   additional voucher specimens and advanced statistical techniques
   including canonical variates analysis and principal component analysis.
   Our new investigations indicate that V. marmoratus represents a
   composite species, comprising at least three distinct taxa. Hence, the
   populations of the Sulu Archipelago (Tawi-Tawi Island) and those of the
   Palawan region are described as new species, viz. Varanus rasmusseni sp.
   nov. and V. palawanensis sp. nov., respectively. The allopatric island
   populations of V. cumingi inhabiting Samar, Leyte, and Bohol (the East
   Visayan subregion) show characteristic and geographically correlated
   colour patterns distinct from the type locality Mindanao (the second
   subregion of Greater Mindanao), warranting subspecific partition of this
   species. The new subspecies is named V. cumingi samarensis ssp. nov. In
   contrast, the taxonomic status of V. nuchalis remained unchanged,
   although this species shows some considerable variation in colour
   pattern. The systematic chapters are supplemented with notes about
   biology and conservation status. The hitherto underestimated diversity
   and zoogeography of Philippine water monitors is discussed in the light
   of Pleistocene sea level fluctuations. Finally, we introduce a scenario
   for the evolution and spread of Southeast Asian water monitor lizards
   and provide an identification key for the Philippine members of the V.
   salvator complex.
C1 Koch, Andre; Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum A. Koenig & Leibniz Institute
   for Biodiversity of Animals, Department of Herpetology, Adenauerallee
   160, D-53113 Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM andrepascalkoch@web.de
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation;
   Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Taxonomy;
   Key; Conservation; Biometrics; Colour and luminescence; Colour;
   Integument; Integumentary derivatives; Evolution; Variation;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Varanus cumingi samarensis [Philippines /  / New subspecies]. 
   Varanus palawanensis; Varanus rasmusseni [Philippines /  / New species].
   
   Varanus salvator complex [Endangered status / Conservation status /
   systematics] [Biometrics / Morphometrics / ] [Markings /  / ] [Scales /
   Scalation / ] [Morphological variation /  / ] [Zoogeography / Endemism &
   palaeozoogeography / ] [Philippines /  / Key to species] [ /  / biology;
   distribution]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Varanidae
OR Varanus cumingi cumingi - Martin 1838 (Varanidae): [Diagnosis, P. 15]. 
   Varanus cumingi samarensis (Varanidae): [Subsp nov, Philippines, P. 19].
   
   Varanus marmoratus - (Wiegmann 1834) (Varanidae): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   27]. 
   Varanus nuchalis - (Guenther 1872) (Varanidae): [Type locality,
   Restricted, p. 40; Redescription, Holotype, p. 41]. 
   Varanus palawanensis (Varanidae): [Sp nov, Philippines, P. 33]. 
   Varanus rasmusseni (Varanidae): [Sp nov, Philippines, P. 28].

DT Article
TI Octoglena claraqua, n. sp. (Polyzoniida: Hirudisomatidae), a new
   milliped from Idaho, USA; first record of the order from the western
   interior of North America.
AU Shelley, Rowland M. (rowland.shelley@ncdenr.gov) 
   Richart, Casey H.
   Bogan, Arthur E.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2446
PS 55-64
PD 6 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2446.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02446p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The milliped family Hirudisomatidae (Polyzoniida) comprises two genera
   in the Western Hemisphere and North America - Octoglena Wood, 1864, and
   Mexiconium Shelley, 1996 - and seven species, one being a new species
   from Idaho, the first hirudisomatid from the western interior,
   represented solely by an adult male. It is unique in its banded color
   pattern, recumbent gonopodal orientation in situ, upright anterior
   gonopod podomeres relative to the sternum, and the calyx configuration
   of the ultimate article. Despite these features, provisional assignment
   to Octoglena is warranted pending more material and review of all
   familial components under high magnification, preferably SEM. A full
   description is provided for O. claraqua, n. sp., along with a key to
   familial components in the Western Hemisphere, new locality records, and
   a distribution map.
C1 Shelley, Rowland M.; Research Laboratory, North Carolina State Museum of
   Natural Sciences, MSC #126, Raleigh, NC 27699-1626, USA, USA.
EM rowland.shelley@ncdenr.gov

   region; North America; USA

   / Distribution] [North America /  / ] [ / Western interior / New record]
   [Idaho /  / ]. 
   Octoglena anura [Oregon /  / New record] [Washington /  / ]. 
   Octoglena bivirgata [California /  / New record]. 
   Octoglena claraqua [Idaho /  / New species].

   Polyzoniida (Diplopoda): [New record].

DT Article
TI The taxonomy of Ogyris halmaturia (Tepper, 1890) stat. nov.
   (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae).
AU Grund, Roger (rgrund@chariot.net.au) 
SO Australian Journal of Entomology
VL 49
IS 2
PS 114-120
PD 5 May 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ogyris halmaturia (Tepper, 1890) was unwittingly founded on two
   different taxons, comprising the O. halmaturia and also O. otanes (C. &
   R. Felder, 1865). For the past 116 years, O. halmaturia has been treated
   primarily either as a geographical subspecies or as a synonym of Ogyris
   idmo (Hewitson, 1862). Recently in 2008, it was proposed to synonymise
   O. halmaturia with O. otanes, and Ogyris waterhouseri (Bethune-Baker,
   1905) was elevated as the replacement name for O. halmaturia. In this
   paper the taxonomic status of O. halmaturia is reviewed and it is
   considered to be valid, while O. waterhouseri is considered to be a
   junior subjective synonym of O. halmaturia. Comparisons of adult and
   juvenile morphologies for allied species, and of DNA attributes indicate
   O. halmaturia is specifically distinct. The common name Eastern Large
   Bronze Azure is proposed for O. halmaturia.
C1 Grund, Roger; 9 Parkers Rd, Torrens Pk, SA, Australia, Australia.
EM rgrund@chariot.net.au
SC Zoology
SN 1326-6756
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Lycaenidae
OR Ogyris halmaturia - (Tepper 1890) (Lycaenidae): [Senior synonym, Of
   Ogyris waterhouseri (Bethune-Baker 1905), p. 118; Removal from synonymy,
   With Ogyris otanes (Felder & Felder 1865), p. 114]. 
   Ogyris otanes - (Felder & Felder 1865) (Lycaenidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Ogyris halmaturia (Tepper 1890), p. 114]. 
   Ogyris waterhouseri - (Bethune-Baker 1905) (Lycaenidae): [Junior
   synonym, Of Ogyris halmaturia (Tepper 1890), p. 118]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14611074319

TI Bocathrips okajimai gen. et sp. n. (Thysanoptera, Phlaeothripidae), an
   Australian fungus-feeding thrips.
AU Goldarazena, Arturo (agoldarazena@neiker.net) 
SO Australian Journal of Entomology
VL 49
IS 2
PS 121-125
PD 5 May 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new genus and species of Thysanoptera, Phlaeothripidae, Bocathrips
   okajimai, is described from dead branches in the Australian Capital
   Territory, Australia. This thrips is unusual in having a remarkably
   long-mouth cone but very short maxillary stylets. The species presumably
   feeds on fungal hyphae growing on dead branches.

DT Article
TI Australasian Stictocladius Edwards (Diptera: Chironomidae) diagnosed and
   described.
AU Cranston, Peter S. (pscranston@ucdavis.edu) 
   Saether, Ole A.
SO Australian Journal of Entomology
VL 49
IS 2
PS 126-144
PD 5 May 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The first formal generic diagnosis for the immature stages and females,
   and a more complete diagnosis of the males of Stictocladius, based on
   extensive material from the southern continents, are provided.
   Associated immature stages are described in detail for the previously
   described Australasian species, Stictocladius lacuniferus (Freeman), New
   Zealand; S. pictus (Freeman), New Zealand; S. multiserialis (Freeman),
   Australia; S. uniserialis (Freeman), Australia; S. victoriae (Freeman),
   Australia. Divergent species Stictocladius sofour sp. n. from eastern
   Australia and Stictocladius occidentalis sp. n. from western Australia
   are described. The further existence of undescribed additional
   diversity, notably from tropical Australia and the Neotropics, is noted:
   the morphology of these specimens is incorporated in the generic
   diagnoses. Stictocladius is compared with putatively related
   Diplocladius Kieffer and Heleniella Gowin, and the very likely sister
   group, Lopescladius Oliviera.
C1 Cranston, Peter S.; Univ Calif Davis, Dept Entomol, 1 Shields Ave,
   Davis, CA, USA, USA.
EM pscranston@ucdavis.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1326-6756

   Key; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia; Australia

   [New South Wales /  / ].

DT Article
TI Long-legged cave spiders (Araneae, Telemidae) from Yunnan-Guizhou
   Plateau, southwestern China.
AU Lin, Yucheng
   Li, Shuqiang (lisq@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2445
PS 1-34
PD 5 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2445.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02445p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ten new species of the genus Telema, occurring in caves of
   Yunnan-Guizhou Plateau of southwestern China, are described and
   illustrated. Nine of these, T. bifida sp. nov., T. strentarsi sp. nov.,
   T. spirae sp. nov., T. tortutheca sp. nov., T. spinafemora sp. nov., T.
   pedati sp. nov., T. conglobare sp. nov., T. guihua sp. nov. and T.
   vesiculata sp. nov., have the typical troglobiotic characters, i.e., no
   eyes, long legs and setae, pale somatic coloration, and without pigment
   pattern. Another species, T. auricoma sp. nov., found in several caves,
   may be a troglomorphic species, has relatively short legs, six eyes, and
   brightly pigmented body. Nine known Telema species occurring in caves of
   this region are also briefly reported. The key to species was provided.
   Diversity of cave-dwelling telemid spiders in this region was discussed.
C1 Li, Shuqiang; Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing
   100101, China, China.
EM lisq@ioz.ac.cn

   region; Eurasia; Asia; China

TI Two new Stephanostomum-like cercariae (Digenea: Acanthocolpidae) from
   Nassarius dorsatus and N. olivaceus (Gastropoda: Nassariidae) in Central
   Queensland, Australia.
AU Barnett, Leonie J. (l.barnett@cqu.edu.au) 
   Miller, Terrence L.
   Cribb, Thomas H.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2445
PS 35-52
PD 5 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2445.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02445p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new Stephanostomum-like cercariae, Cercaria capricornia VII and
   Cercaria capricornia VIII (Digenea: Acanthocolpidae), are described from
   the nassariid gastropods Nassarius dorsatus and Nassarius olivaceus
   collected from the intertidal zone in the Capricornia region of Central
   Queensland, Australia. Morphological analysis of these new cercariae was
   augmented with DNA sequence data from the large subunit (LSU) ribosomal
   DNA region to aid in identification. Bayesian inference analysis of the
   LSU rDNA revealed that these putative acanthocolpid cercariae nested
   well within a clade containing species of Stephanostomum, which along
   with morphological data, suggests they are species of Stephanostomum.
   Comparative analysis of LSU rDNA sequences also indicates that these two
   cercariae are not S. adlardi, S. bicoronatum, S. tantabiddii or S. cf.
   uku, all species known from Australian fishes. The secondary structure
   of the internal transcribed spacer 2 (ITS2) rDNA region was inferred for
   these two cercariae using minimum free energy modelling algorithms. Both
   cercarial types displayed a four helix ITS2 secondary structure model
   and differed from each other by two compensatory base changes (CBCs) and
   nine hemi-CBCs.
C1 Barnett, Leonie J.; Centre for Environmental Management, CQ University
   Australia, Bruce Highway, North Rockhampton, Queensland 4702, Australia,
   Australia.
EM l.barnett@cqu.edu.au
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Cercaria capricornia VII [Molluscan hosts / Nassarius dorsatus / New
   parasite species] [ / Nassarius olivaceus / ] [South Pacific /
   Australia, Queensland / New species from molluscan host]. 
   Cercaria capricornia VIII [Molluscan hosts / Nassarius dorsatus / New
   parasite species] [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / New species
   from molluscan host]. 
   Nassarius dorsatus [Digenean parasites / Cercaria capricornia VII / New
   parasite species] [ / Cercaria capricornia VIII / ] [South Pacific /

   Nassarius olivaceus [Digenean parasites / Cercaria capricornia VII / New

DT Article
TI A new species of Chaunax (Lophiiformes: Chuanacidae) from the western
   South Pacific, with comment on C. latipunctatus.
AU Ho, Hsuan-Ching
   Shao, Kwang-Tsao (zoskt@gate.sinica.edu.tw) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2445
PS 53-61
PD 5 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2445.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02445p061.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of anglerfish, Chaunax nudiventer, is described on the
   basis of 35 specimens from the western South Pacific Ocean. It is
   characterized by large spots on the dorsal surface; a largely naked area
   on abdomen; a relatively short head and long tail, both reflected in the
   elongated body; slender and simple spines on body surface; numerous
   broad flaps on lateral side of body; and higher number of lateral line
   neuromasts: mainly 41-43 in lateral line proper, 4 in the upper
   peropercular series, and 16-17 in the pectoral series. Comments on a
   similar species, C. latipunctatus from the eastern South Pacific Ocean,
   is provided.
C1 Shao, Kwang-Tsao; Biodiversity Research Center, Academia Sinica, 128,
   sec. 2, Academia Rd, Taipei 115, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM zoskt@gate.sinica.edu.tw

   Ocean

AB Two new species, Dichopelmus lotus n. sp. (Eriophyidae) and Trimeroptes

DT Article
TI Mammals from the Blue Ash local fauna (Late Oligocene), South Dakota.
   Rodentia part 5: family Cricetidae.
AU Korth, William W. (wwkorth@frontiernet.net) 
SO Paludicola
VL 7
IS 4
PS 117-136
PD 4 May 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ten species of cricetid rodents are identified from the Blue Ash fauna
   including three new species, Eumys brachyodus, E. parvidens, Scottimus
   sp., cf. S. longiquus, S. kellamorum. Leidymys sp., cf. L. blacki, L.
   juxtaparvnlus n. sp., Paciculus dakotensis n. sp., P. sp., cf. P.
   nebraskensis, Geringia copiosus n. sp., and an indeterminate species.
   The cricetids are the best represented and one of the most diverse
   families of rodents from the Blue Ash anthill fauna. Some of the genera
   of cricetids present in the fauna are more characteristic of the
   Arikareean land mammal age (Leidymys, Paciculus, Geringia), but the
   species are either smaller or morphologically more primitive than those
   from the Arikareean. However, three species in the fauna (E. brachyodus,
   E. parvidens, S. longiquus) are currently only known from the Orellan or
   Whitneyan. It appears that the age of the Blue Ash fauna, based on the
   cricetid rodents, is somewhere near the Whitneyan-Arikareean boundary.
C1 Korth, William W.; Rochester Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology, 265
   Carling Road, Rochester, NY 14610, USA, USA.
EM wwkorth@frontiernet.net
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Paleontology

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Skeleton; Dentition; Ecology; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

DT Article
TI A new chub (Actinopterygii, Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae) from the Middle
   Miocene (Early Clarendonian) Aldrich Station Formation, Lyon County,
   Nevada.
AU Kelly, Thomas S.
SO Paludicola
VL 7
IS 4
PS 137-157
PD 4 May 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new chub, Lavinia lugaskii, is described from the middle Miocene
   (early Clarendonian) Aldrich Station Formation of Lyon County, Nevada.
   Lavinia lugaskii represents a basal member of the Lavinia-Hesperoleucus
   lineage, indicating that this lineage diverged from a common ancestor
   with Mylopharodon before 12.5 [long dash] 12.0 million years before
   present. This is the oldest recognized species of Lavinia and the first
   new chub species to be documented from the Miocene of Nevada in over 30
   years.

   Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles,
   California 90007, USA, USA.

   [Miocene /  / ].

   / Early Clarendonian / ].

DT Article
TI New records of Marsupialia, Lipotyphla, and primates from the Duchesnean
   (Middle Eocene) Simi Valley landfill local fauna, Sespe Formation,
   California.
AU Kelly, Thomas S.
SO Paludicola
VL 7
IS 4
PS 158-169
PD 4 May 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A paleontologic mitigation program at the Simi Valley Landfill and
   Recycling Center, Ventura County, California, has yielded significant
   new samples of isolated small mammal teeth from the Duchesnean (middle
   Eocene) Simi Valley Landfill Local Fauna of the Sespe Formation. New
   records of a marsupial, lipotyphlans, and a microsyopid primate for this
   local fauna include: Herpetotherium sp., Batodonoides walshi n. sp., cf.
   Oligoryctes (genus and species undetermined), and cf. Uintasorex sp. In
   addition, significantly larger samples of the erinaceomorph lipotyphlan
   Sespedectes singularis and the marsupial Peradectes californicus are now
   recorded from the Simi Valley Landfill Local Fauna.

DT Article
TI Revision of the Afrotropical flea beetle genus Serraphula Jacoby and
   description of Bechynella, a new genus from Western and Central Africa
   (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Alticinae).
AU Biondi, Maurizio (biondi@univaq.it) 
   D'Alessandro, Paola
SO Zootaxa
VL 2444
PS 1-44
PD 4 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2444.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02444p044.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper a revision of the Afrotropical flea beetle genus
   Serraphula Jacoby, 1897 is reported. Three species previously attributed
   to this genus are transferred to the new genus Bechynella gen. n. and
   the following new combinations are established: Bechynella bohumilae
   (Bechyne, 1955) comb. n.; Bechynella pallens (Bechyne, 1955) comb. n.;
   Bechynella sesengensis (Bechyne, 1959) comb. n. The genus Serraphula
   includes currently 19 species, 16 of which are new to science:
   Serraphula aenea Jacoby, 1897; S. elongata Jacoby, 1900; S. puncticollis
   Bryant, 1944; S. alticola sp. n.; S. audisiana sp. n.; S. bulirschi sp.
   n.; S. colonnellii sp. n.; S. debiasei sp. n.; S. drakensbergensis sp.
   n.; S. duplessisi sp. n.; S. grobbelaariae sp. n.; S. monticola sp. n.;
   S. mpumalangaensis sp. n.; S. natalensis sp. n.; S. oberprieleri sp. n.;
   S. osellai sp. n.; S. transvaalensis sp. n.; S. uysi sp. n.; S. wittmeri
   sp. n. Lectotypes for S. aenea, S. elongata and S. puncticollis are
   designated. A key to all the species is presented as well as line
   drawings of male and female genitalia, scanning electron micrographs of
   some diagnostic morphological characters, and autoecological and
   distributional data.

   L'Aquila, 67010 Coppito - L'Aquila, Italy, Italy.

AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02444p057.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The eight species included by Wood and Bright (1992) in the
   Palaeotropical scolytine genus Hadrodemius Wood are reviewed. The
   following new synonymy is proposed: Hadrodemius comans (Sampson) (=
   Xyleborus amorphus Eggers syn.n., = Xyleborus metacomans Eggers syn.n.),
   Hadrodemius globus (Blandford) (= Xyleborus tomentosus Eggers syn.n.),
   Hadrodemius pseudocomans (Eggers) (= Xyleborus artecomans Schedl
   syn.n.). Hadrodemius (Xyleborus) pubifer (Schedl) is transferred to the
   genus Coptodryas Wood. Xyleborus melli Schedl is misplaced by Wood &
   Bright (1992) as a synonym of Hadrodemius amorphus and is here
   transferred to Xylosandrus Reitter. The following new synonymy is
   proposed: Xylosandrus amputatus (Blandford) (= Xyleborus melli Schedl
   syn.n.). A key to the females of the three species now included in the
   genus is provided. The taxonomy, distribution and biology of the species
   are briefly reviewed, and some new records included.
C1 Beaver, Roger A.; 16/2 Mu 5, Soi Wat Pranon, T.Donkaew, A. Maerim,
   Chiangmai 501080, Thailand, Thailand.
EM rogerbeaver6@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Coptodryas pubifer [Brunei /  / New record]. 
   Hadrodemius comans [Brunei /  / New record] [Laos /  / ] [Thailand /  /
   ] [Vietnam /  / ]. 
   Hadrodemius globus [Vietnam /  / New record].

   Curculionidae

   Transferred from Hadrodemius, p. 55; New record]. 
   Hadrodemius - Wood 1980 (Curculionidae): [Diagnosis, P. 52; Key to

   Hadrodemius comans - (Sampson 1919) (Curculionidae): [Syn nov, Xyleborus
   amorphus Eggers 1926, p. 54; Syn nov, Xyleborus metacomans Eggers 1930,

PT J
AN ZOOR14607049073
DT Article
TI A taxonomic revision of the tarantula spider genus Coremiocnemis Simon
   1892 (Araneae, Theraphosidae), with further notes on the
   Selenocosmiinae.
AU West, Rick C. (rickcwest@shaw.ca) 
   Nunn, Steven C.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2443
PS 1-64
PD 3 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02443p064.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02443p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The selenocosmiine genus Coremiocnemis Simon 1892 is revised for the
   first time with six new species included. Five new species are from West
   Malaysia: C. brachyramosa sp. nov. from Gunung Ledang, Johor; C.
   gnathospina sp. nov. and C. hoggi sp. nov. from Fraser's Hill, Selangor;
   C. jeremyhuffi sp. nov. from Tapah, Perak, Fraser's Hill, Selangor to
   Pahang and C. obscura sp. nov. from Taiping, Perak to Cameron Highlands,
   Pahang. C. kotacana sp. nov. is described from Aceh Teneggara, Sumatra,
   being the first record of this genus outside Malaysia or Australia. A
   lectotype and para- lectotype are designated for C. cunicularia (Simon
   1892). All but two of Abraham's non-type C. valida Pocock 1895 (Abraham
   1924) specimens held in both the NHM and RMBR are newly transferred to
   C. cunicularia. Abraham's two remaining specimens are removed from
   Coremiocnemis. C. valida is redescribed, its former dubious locality is
   resolved. Zoogeographic considerations of all species are discussed and
   resolved. Ontogenetic variation within Coremiocnemis is discussed.
   Several new characters are introduced. Subfamilial relationships with
   proposed sister genera Selenocosmia Ausserer 1871 and Lyrognathus Pocock
   1895 are discussed. A key to species is provided.
C1 West, Rick C.; 3436 Blue Sky Place, Victoria, BC, V9C 3N5, Canada,
   Canada.
EM rickcwest@shaw.ca
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Coremiocnemis [Brunei /  / Distribution; systematics] [Indonesia /
   Sumatra / New record] [Malaysia /  / ]. 
   Coremiocnemis brachyramosa; Coremiocnemis gnathospina; Coremiocnemis
   hoggi; Coremiocnemis jeremyhuffi; Coremiocnemis obscura [Malaysia /  /
   New species]. 
   Coremiocnemis kotacana [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Coremiocnemis - Simon 1892 (Araneae): [Key to species, Females, p. 8;
   New record]. 
   Coremiocnemis brachyramosa (Araneae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 16]. 
   Coremiocnemis cuniculariua - (Simon 1892) (Araneae): [Redescription,
   Female, p. 9]. 
   Coremiocnemis gnathospina (Araneae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 24]. 
   Coremiocnemis hoggi (Araneae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 28]. 
   Coremiocnemis jeremyhuffi (Araneae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 38]. 
   Coremiocnemis kotacana (Araneae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 46]. 
   Coremiocnemis obscura (Araneae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 51]. 
   Coremiocnemis valida - Pocock 1895 (Araneae): [Redescription, Female, p.
   57]. 
   Phlogius cunicularius - Simon 1892 (Araneae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   10]. 
   Selenocosmia tahanensis - Abraham 1924 (Araneae): [Taxonomic position,
   P. 63].

TI New coelotine spiders from Xishuangbanna Rainforest, southwestern China,
   (Araneae: Amaurobiidae).
AU Liu, Jie

U1 0

AB Four new species of coelotine species from Xishuangbanna Rainforest,
   Yunnan, China are described: Coelotes forficatus sp. nov., Draconarius
   bannaensis sp. nov., Draconarius exiguus sp. nov. and Draconarius
   turriformis sp. nov. Morphological descriptions and illustrations of all
   the four new species are given. The type specimens are deposited in the
   Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing.

TI Four new species of the family Diptilomiopidae (Acari: Eriophyoidea)
   from China.
AU Wang, Guo-Quan
   Wei, Sui-Gai
   Yang, Ding (dyangcau@126.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2442
PS 39-50
PD 3 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2442.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02442p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of eriophyoid mites are described and illustrated from
   China. Three of these species are in the subfamily Rhyncaphytoptinae:
   Hyborhinus linderae sp. nov. infesting Lindera obtusiloba Blume
   (Lauraceae); Neocatarhinus dendrocalamus sp. nov. infesting
   Dendrocalamus latiflorus Munro (Poaceae) and Rhinophytoptus tremae sp.
   nov. infesting Trema cannabina Lour. (Ulmaceae); and one in the
   subfamily Diptilomiopinae: Vimola emarginata sp. nov. infesting
   Terminalia sp. (Combretaceae).

AN ZOOR14607049078
DT Article
TI Syndesmis patagonica n. sp. (Rhabdocoela: Umagillidae) from the sea
   urchin Arbacia dufresnii (Echinodermata: Echinoidea) in Patagonia,
   Argentina.
AU Brogger, Martin I. (mbrogger@bg.fcen.uba.ar) 
   Ivanov, Veronica A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2442
PS 59-68
PD 3 May 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2442.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02442p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The umagillid Syndesmis patagonica n. sp. is described from the
   intestinal tract of the sea urchin Arbacia dufresnii, which represents a
   new host record for the genus. The hosts were collected from the coast
   of Patagonia (Argentina), and S. patagonica n. sp. is the first species
   of Syndesmis reported from South America. Syndesmis patagonica n. sp.
   can be distinguished from all other species in the genus by the
   possession of a stylet that is extremely short (less than 50 [mu]m
   long), and a combination of other characters including the position of
   the testes, body size, body color and host. An updated overview of the
   distribution of all species of Syndesmis is also presented
C1 Brogger, Martin I.; CONICET, Lab. de Ecosistemas Costeros, Museo
   Argentino de Ciencias Naturales "Bernardino Rivadavia", Av. Angel
   Gallardo 470, C1405DJR, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Argentina.
EM mbrogger@bg.fcen.uba.ar

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   zones; Atlantic Ocean

   [South Atlantic / Argentina / New associated platyhelminth species] [ /
   Argentina, Patagonia / Platyhelminth associates].

DT Article
TI First occurrence of Lingulepis (Brachiopoda-Obolidae) from the Devonian
   of the Parana state, Brazil.
FT Primeira ocorrencia de Lingulepis (Brachiopoda-Obolidae) no Devoniano do
   estado do Parana, Brasil.
AU Pinto Bosetti, Elvio (elvio.bosetti@pq.cnpq.br) 
   Scalise Horodyski, Rodrigo
   Zabini, Carolina
   Matsumura, Willian Mikio Kurita
   Godoy, Luiz Carlos
SO Boletim do Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi Ciencias Naturais
VL 5
IS 2
PS 151-164
PD maio-agosto 2010
PY 2010
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The brachiopod fauna of the Parana State Devonian sucession
   (Neo-Lochkovian [long dash] Frasnian) is known for a long time. In the
   present paper a new species of Brachiopoda, Lingulepis wagoneri sp. nov.
   (Linguliformea [long dash] Lingulata [long dash] Obolidae) is recorded
   and described for the Parana Basin Devonian. It is the first occurrence
   of this genus in Brazil. All specimens were preserved in siltstone shale
   and dark-gray siltstone and were collected in Ponta Grossa and Tibagi
   outcrops, located in the eastern portion of the Parana Basin.
C1 Pinto Bosetti, Elvio; Universidade Estadual de Ponta Grossa,
   Departamento de Geociencias, Ponta Grossa, Parana, Brazil, Brazil.
EM elvio.bosetti@pq.cnpq.br

   South America; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates

PS 113-119
PD May-August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Coronelaps g. n. is presented to allocate the species Calamaria lepida
   Reinhard, 1861. The new genus is characterized by the presence of a
   yellow collar on the head, by general back coloration red with three
   very thin dark stripes that disappear in the development; by skull bones
   as the basioccipital process strongly developed, transverse suture
   between supraoccipital and exoccipital, and aspects of teeth, and
   hemipenis. It differs from others species of Elapomorphus, where which
   is located, by the long body with the same diameter along it; head
   short; from Phalotris, by the presence of paired prefrontals; and from
   Apostolepis, by the presence of paired internasals and prefrontals, and
   by the absence of the black tail blotch. This species was confounded
   with Elapomorphus wuchereri Gunther, 1861, and the later, with
   Elapomorphus quinquelineatus (Raddi, 1820).
C1 Lema, Thales De; Museu de Ciencias e Tecnologia, Pontificia Universidade
   Catolica do Rio Grande do Sul, Av. Ipiranga, 6681, Caixa Postal 1429,
   90619-900, Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil, Brazil.
EM thalesdelema@terra.com.br
SC Zoology
SN 1809-9939
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Key
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Serpentes, Colubridae
OR Calamaria lepida - Reinhardt 1861 (Colubridae): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Coronelaps, p. 114]. 
   Coronelaps (Colubridae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Elapomorphini, Type species
   Calamaria lepida Reinhardt 1861, p. 114]. 
   Coronelaps lepidus - (Reinhardt 1861) (Colubridae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Calamaria, p. 115]. 
   Elapomorphini (Colubridae): [Key to genera, P. 115]. 
   Elapomorphus wuchereri - Guenther 1861 (Colubridae): [Status, P. 115].

PT J

DT Article
TI Cyclopertorbitolites, a new soritid (Foraminifera) from the Lower Eocene
   of the Eskisehir and Kastamonu regions (Turkey).
AU Ozgen-Erdem, N. (nozgen@cumhuriyet.edu.tr) 
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 3
PS 3-10
PD Mai-Iyun 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
   Separate unpaginated plate.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Lower Eocene sediments in the southwestern Seyitgazi (Eskisehir)
   Region include shallow-water rhythmic deposition of claystones,
   limestones, clayey limestones, and sandy limestones. The Lower Eocene
   unit in the northwestern Tosya (Kastamonu) Region is composed of
   shallow-water limestones. Both units contain a new soritid foraminiferal
   genus, Cyclopertorbitolites (with the type species Cyclopertorbitolites
   tokerae sp. nov.). Cyclopertorbitolites tokerae gen. et sp. nov is
   described in the Middle Ilerdian[long dash]Lower Cuisian sediments of
   Seyitgazi and in the Middle Ilerdian limestones of Tosya in this study.
   It is characterized by the presence of regular annular chambers with
   rectangular or subrectangular chamberlets at the juvenile stage and a
   porcellaneous lamina on either side of the test.
C1 Ozgen-Erdem, N.; Cumhuriyet University, Department of Geological
   Engineering, Sivas, Turkey, Turkey.
EM nozgen@cumhuriyet.edu.tr
SC Zoology
SN 0031-031X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Cyclopertorbitolites [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Cyclopertorbitolites tokerae [Turkey /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea,
   Foraminiferida
OR Cyclopertorbitolites (Foraminiferida): [Gen nov, Of family Soritidae,
   Type species Cyclopertorbitolites tokerae, p. 7, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Cyclopertorbitolites tokerae (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, Turkey, Eocene,
   P. 8; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A discovery of the genus Cabrieroceras (Werneroceratidae, Ammonoidea) in
   Salair.
AU Nikolaeva, S.V. (44svnikol@mail.ru) 
   Bakharev, N.K.
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 3
PS 11-17
PD Mai-Iyun 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
   Unpaginated plate.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The ammonoid genus Cabrieroceras Bogoslovsky is recorded for the first
   time from the Eifelian of Salair (probably from the Safonovo Horizon).
   These ammonoids date the host rocks as the Cabrieroceras crisp forme
   Zone, recognized in many sections in Western Europe, North America, and
   North Africa. The taxonomy of the genus Cabrieroceras is discussed, and
   a new species, C. salairicum Nikolaeva, is described.
C1 Nikolaeva, S.V.; Paleontologicheskii institut im. A.A. Borisyaka RAN,
   Russia, Russia.
EM 44svnikol@mail.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0031-031X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Cabrieroceras [Russia /  / distribution; new record] [Devonian /
   Eifelian / ]. 
   Cabrieroceras salairicum [Russia /  / new species] [Devonian /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Anarcestida
OR Cabrieroceras (Anarcestida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Cabrieroceras salairicum - Nikolaeva 2010 (Anarcestida): [Sp nov,
   Russia, Devonian, P. 15; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Ostracodes from the Upper Permian Khivach Formation in Kolyma-Omolon
   Basin.
AU Molostovskaya, I.I. (molostI@yandez.ru) 
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 3
PS 38-41
PD Mai-Iyun 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
   Separate unpaginated plate.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ostracodes Healdianella splendida Belousova, Paraparchites ganelini sp.
   nov., Paraparchites? hivachensis sp. nov and Arcibairdia vodopadniensis
   sp. nov are described from the Upper Permian deposits of the Khivach
   Formation (Kolyma[long dash]Omolon Basin, Eastern Siberia).
   Paraparchites species most closely resemble ancient Paleozoic ostracodes
   of the Boreal province. Valve morphology of Healdianella and Acribairdia
   points to their similarity to ostracodes from the upper levels of the
   Upper Permian of the Tethyan realm.
C1 Molostovskaya, I.I.; Saratovskii gosudarstvennyi universitet im. N.G.
   Chernyshevskogo, Russia, Russia.
EM molostI@yandez.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0031-031X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Arcibairdia vodopadniensis; Paraparchites ganelini; Paraparchites?
   hivatshensis [Russia /  / new species] [Permian /  / ]. 
   Ostracoda [Russia / Siberia, Kolyma-Omolon Basin / stratigraphical
   distribution; systematics] [Permian / Upper Permian / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda

AN ZOOR14703022533
DT Article
TI A new genus and species of oribatid mite, Cretaceobodes martinezae gen.
   et sp. nov., from the Lower Cretaceous amber of San Just (Teruel
   Province, Spain) (Acariformes, Oribatida, Otocepheidae).
AU Arillo, A. (aarillo@teleline.es) 
   Subias, L.S.
   Shtanchaeva, U.
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 3
PS 42-45
PD Mai-Iyun 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new fossil genus and species of oribatid mite, Cretaceobodes
   martinezae gen. et sp. nov., belonging to the family Otocepheidae is
   described. The new species is preserved in a piece of amber from the San
   just outcrop (Teruel Province, Spain), which is believed to be Albian in
   age. The new genus is compared with the extant genus Carabocepheus
   Berlese, 1910 and its relationships with the superfamilies Otocepheoidea
   and Carabodoidea are discussed. Carabocepheidae is regarded as a junior
   synonym of Otocepheidae. Ranking Carabocepheus lounsbury latior Balogh
   et Mahunka, 1966 as a separate species is proposed.
C1 Arillo, A.; Departamento de Zoologia y Antropologia Fisica, Facultad de
   Biologia, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, Spain, Spain.
EM aarillo@teleline.es
SC Zoology
SN 0031-031X

   Status; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic

   Cretaceobodes martinezae [Spain /  / new species; Described from amber]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari

   Carabocepheus latior - Balogh & Mahunka 1966 (Acari): [Raised from,
   Carabocepheus lounsburyi latior, p. 44]. 
   Carabocepheus lounsburyi latior - Balogh & Mahunka 1966 (Acari): [Raised
   to, Carabocepheus latior, p. 44]. 
   Cretaceobodes (Acari): [Gen nov, Of family Otocepheidae, Type species
   Cretaceobodes martinezae, p. 43, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Cretaceobodes martinezae (Acari): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P. 44,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Otocepheidae (Acari): [Syn nov, Carabocepheidae Mahunka 1986, p. 44].

AB Two new species of Protopanorpa Carpenter (Mecoptera: Permochoristidae),
   P. longicubitalis sp. nov and P. similis sp. nov from the Ufimian
   Solikamsk Horizon of the Perm Region (Tyulkino locality) are described.
   Scorpionflies ofTyulkino are compared with scorpionflies of the
   Kungurian Chekarda locality (Penn Region) and the Early Kazanian Soyana
   locality (Arkhangelsk Region).

TI A new genus of elateriform beetles (Coleoptera, Polyphaga) from the
   Jurassic of Daohugou, China.
AU Yan, E.V. (yan-e@mail.ru) 
   Wang, B.

AB A new coleopteran genus, Parelateriformius, gen. nov., comprising the
   species P. communis, sp. nov., P. villosus, sp. nov., P. capitifossus,
   sp. nov., and P. mirabdominis, sp. nov., is described from Daohugou
   deposits, Inner Mongolia, China, and is assigned to the infraorder
   Elateriformia. The systematic position of the new genus within the
   suborder Polyphaga is discussed.

DT Article
TI A new tribe of fossil digger wasps (Insecta: Hymenoptera, Crabronidae)
   from the Rovno Amber, Eocene of Ukraine.
AU Antropov, A.V. (antropov@zmmu.msu.ru) 
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 3
PS 65-73
PD Mai-Iyun 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
   Separate unpaginated plates.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new tribe of digger wasps, Protomicroidini trib. nov. (Hymenoptera,
   Crabronidae), including a known species Protomicroides sororius gen. et
   sp. nov. is described from the Upper Eocene Rovno a Ukraine. The new
   tribe combines features characteristic of several tribes of the
   Crabroninae and is a group of the extant tribe Oxybelini. The most
   distinctive characters of the new tribe include nonelongatt podeum with
   strongly developed lateral keel and enclosed dorsal area; semioval
   postscutellum with a lamelate border; absence of pygidial plate,
   psammophores, and digging tarsal rakes; and considerably reduced
   forewing venation.
C1 Antropov, A.V.; Zoologicheskii muzei Moskovskogo gosudarstvennogo
   universiteta, Russia, Russia.
EM antropov@zmmu.msu.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0031-031X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Protomicroides [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Protomicroides sororius [Ukraine /  / new species; Described from amber]
   [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Protomicroidini [Eocene /  / New tribe]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Sphecoidea, Sphecidae
OR Protomicroides (Sphecidae): [Gen nov, Of new tribe Protomicroidini, Type
   species Protomicroides sororius, p. 67, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Protomicroides sororius (Sphecidae): [Sp nov, Ukraine, Eocene, P. 70,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Protomicroidini (Sphecidae): [Tribe nov, Of subfamily Crabroninae, Type
   genus Protomicroides, p. 66, Eocene; Fossil].

TI Neogene phasianids (Aves: Phasianidae) of Central Asia: 3. genera
   Lophogallus gen. nov and Syrmaticus.
AU Zelenkov, N.V. (nzelen@paleo.ru) 
   Kurochkin, E.N.
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 3
PS 79-87
PD Mai-Iyun 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
   Separate unpaginated plate.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Large phasianids from four Miocene and Pliocene localities of Mongolia
   are reviewed. Lophogallus naranbulakensis gen. et sp. nov from the
   Middle Miocene of the Naran Bulak locality is described. It resembles
   extant Gallus, Lophura, and partially Pavo. The fossil pheasant
   Syrmaticus kozlovae Kurochkin is compared in detail with other Neogene
   and living pheasants. The stratigraphic position of phasianids from
   Neogene localities of Central Asia is discussed.
C1 Zelenkov, N.V.; Paleontologicheskii institut im. A.A. Borisyaka RAN,
   Russia, Russia.
